loans.name: Suad

texts.en:
Suad is a housewife and mother of two sons and one daughter. Suad's husband is a Palestinian National Authority employee who also has a small grocery store in the city. Suad helps her husband by working in the store when he is at his daily work.

Suad and her husband wanted to improve the shop and add few shelves and fridge with a display window, so Suad came to FATEN to take a $1,000 loan for this purpose. 
Suad and her husband are working hard to secure their kids future and are saving to have a bigger store which serves more customers.
Suad's husband appears in the picture here in the store as Suad is a conservative woman who is not comfortable having her picture published.

loans.use: Improve the store

loans.name: Bong

texts.en:
Bong S., 26, is married and resides with his wife and a child in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. S. is a tuk-tuk driver, earning an income of $5 per day. S.’s wife sells meatballs, earning an income of $5 per day.  

S. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a plot of land to sell meatballs. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot land for his wife to sell meatballs

loans.name: Hoa

texts.en: Hoa T. H. is 28 years old. She lives with her family in Xuan non commune. In 2003, she opened a shop that sells soft drinks and beer. Her shop is always crowded with customers in summer. She can earn a stable income to manage her daily life. She has used her loans very effectively in expanding her shop. Now, she needs to borrow 8,938,000 VND to buy a refrigerator.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator.

loans.name: Len

texts.en:
Len S., 51, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. S. sells dessert and groceries, earning an income of $5 per day. S.’s daughter is a security guard for a private company for an income of $2.50 per day.  

S. is requesting a loan of $300 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Ryskul's Group

texts.en:
Ryskul K. is the leader of this group. She is 54 and a widow who already has a grandson. Now she is an owner of a chemist’s shop. The family budget enlarges with the help of a cattle-breeding business. Her son actively helps to run his mother's business. During the past two years, Ryskul has managed to buy furniture. In order to develop her business she needs to buy hay for cattle feeding. That’s why she wants to get a loan. In the future, her plans include obtaining a new car. 

Gulshat B., 36, is married. Her husband's profession is farming. Together, the couple has three children, all of whom are school pupils. Gulshat has chosen to work in the sphere of medicine; she works as a nurse in a hospital. But in order to cover family expenses, she has to earn money additionally by cattle breeding. Out of those proceeds, the family has managed to build a new house and to obtain a refrigerator and a washing machine. The loan's purpose is for stocking up hay for the winter. In the future, she is planning to buy a car.

Saltanat U. has the status of the group’s treasurer. She is 34 and a widow who has raised two sons by herself. Luckily, she gets material support from her brother and her older son. But after the big tragedy, her husband's death, she decided not to give up and she has opened a small shop. This business gives her 6000 soms per month. Moreover, Saltanat makes her bread by working as a mail carrier. She has managed to buy necessary household appliances: a clothes washer, a refrigerator and a vacuum cleaner. The loan's purpose is to increase cattle stock by obtaining more farm animals (2500 soms per animal). In the future, she plans to build a household room. 

Shailogul T., 31, is married and her spouse is a farmer. Today, she raises money by taking orders at home and offering a sewing service. During the years of working hard, the members of the family together have managed to make house repairs, to buy a television set and a carpet. The loan's purpose is to obtain a sewing machine and stuff. Planning for the future, Shailogul wants to buy a kitchen set and a refrigerator. 

Where Did This Loan Come From?

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase hay

loans.name: Duy

texts.en: Duy T. H. is 29 years old with 2 children who are attending secondary school. She has a small shop that serves breakfasts with a variety of meals such as bread, noodles, and soup. Her shop is crowded with local eaters. She can earn 100,000 VND per day. Now, she needs a loan of 5,014,000 VND to buy more sets of tables and chairs to attract more customers.

loans.use: To buy more sets of tables and chairs to attract more customers.

loans.name: Parveen

texts.en:
Parveen belongs to an industrial city of Pakistan called Gujranwala. She lives in a two-room brick house with her family. She is 40 years old and married to M. H., who has a construction-supplies business.
  
A very talented lady, Parveen is involved in embroidering clothes. She crafts beautiful embroidery designs on clothes, which helps her in attracting more customers toward her talent. She has been making embroidered clothes for the past six years and is getting good earnings from it. 
  
She is the mother of five children. Only her two youngest children are able to get an education. She has delivered her talent to her elder daughters, who now also help her in completing the orders. Her son has a business of selling crockery.  

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, he will buy construction supplies such as cement, bricks and sand in large quantities.
  
Parveen is hopeful that this investment will bring positive changes to her husband’s work and his monthly income will go up. She is a regular loan user of Asasah and has proved herself a responsible client.

loans.use: To buy construction supplies for the business

loans.name: Suy

texts.en:
Suy P., 35, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. P. sells groceries, earning an income of $7 per day. P.’s husband is a tuk-tuk (a motorcycle with a trailer) driver, and he is able to earn an income of $6 per day. 

P. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase more groceries to stock the store. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: Buy more groceries to stock the store

loans.name: Tsendjav

texts.en:
Tsendjav J. is 55 years old and lives with her husband and one daughter in Harhorin, an ancient capital city of the Mongolian Empire. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All of her other children are grown up and live separately from their parents. One daughter, Myagmarjav, attends university and helps her mother's business during the summer months. 

Tsendjav and her husband operate a shoe-making business. She used to work as a boot maker between 1973 and 2000 and began her private business in 2000 by making traditional boots. She has built a stable operation. She attributes her business success to her excellent sewing. Over many years of business, Tsendjav has gained both experience and a wide customer base.  

She is requesting a 1,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan in order to purchase raw materials such as leather, fabric, heels and glue from Narantuul, the largest and main market in Ulaanbaatar, a capital city of Mongolia, for her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials

loans.name: Aida's Group

texts.en: Aida T. has the status of this group’s leader. She is 43 and married to a man whose line of work is farming. The couple is bringing up two schoolchildren. Today, Aida is a schoolteacher. Besides her primary profession, the family started breeding cattle two years ago in order to get extra money. During these years they have managed to equip the house with furniture. Now the family needs a loan to buy paint in order to start repairing their house. In the future, the family intends to finish building the house completely. Baktybek S. is 36 and married. His wife doesn’t work; she keeps house and hearth for her big family. The couple has five daughters, three of whom are schoolgirls. Now the head of the family gets an additional income by working as a taxi driver; in this way, he gets 5000 soms per month. Besides that, he breeds cattle. Baktybek needs a loan to buy his daughters' school writing materials. In the future, he is planning to build a house. Nazgul J. is the treasurer of the group. She is 38 and married. Her husband drives a tractor and a combine. The family has five children: three sons and two daughters, all of whom go to school. Now Nazgul works as a school teacher. Apart from this, the family breeds cattle. By now, they have managed to obtain a combine. The loan's purpose is to buy cement for household building. In the future, the plan is to finish the house up. Baktygul I., is 26 and married. Together with her spouse, who is a farmer, she is raising a small daughter. Baktygul teaches in a school. Besides that, the family makes their bread by cattle breeding. The loan's purpose is to buy three dam (female) sheep for further stock increasing. In the near future, the family is planning to begin building a house. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase paint

loans.name: Luan

texts.en: Luan T. N. is 38 years old with 2 children. One of them is studying at Sport University. Paying for education fees is a big problem for her. To solve this difficulty, she has opened a shop that sells fresh vegetables in the local market. She can earn 100,000 VND profit per day. She joined SEDA in 2009, with a loan of 2,204,000 VND, which she used to expand her shop. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 5,014,000 VND to  invest in her shop.

loans.use: To invest in her shop.

loans.name: Jyparkul's Group

texts.en: Jyparkul O. is the leader of the group. She is 32 and not married. Together with her brother, she breeds and fattens cattle for their further resale. She started this kind of business three years ago, having been in blank despair of that fact that she couldn’t find a job. But during the years of working diligently, she has managed to pay partially for her brother’s studies in university. Jyparkul needs a loan in order to obtain a refrigerator. In the future, she wants to achieve more successful results. Aijan T. is the treasurer of the group. She is 24 and married. Her spouse is a medical worker; he earns money by working as a bone-setter at a salary of 8,000 soms. The couple has a daughter; she is a toddler. Today, Aijan keeps house and brings up the baby. The family by now has managed to obtain furniture. They need a loan in order to buy building materials for a household room. Aijan, with her husband, dreams of opening a big workshop. Turatbek K., 53, is married. His wife has a profession of a garage security guard at a salary of 1500 soms per month. The couple is raising a son, who is a schoolboy. Turatbek supports his family and enriches its funds by fishing and cattle breeding. Two years ago, after having obtained two sheep, he started this kind of business. By now, he has managed to buy a laundry machine. The loan's purpose is to buy two sheep for stock increasing. In the future, he wants to be able to afford a refrigerator. Mahabat O., 32, is married. Her husband works as a refueling operator; by doing this, he makes some money (5000 soms). The couple has two children. Their family gets their main income from cattle breeding. This started two years ago after they purchased three calves. So by now, out of the profits, they have managed to do house repairs. The loan's purpose is to install new gates. The family is planning to pay off the loan from earnings out of the resale of cattle. In the nearer future, Mahabat wants to equip the house and buy furniture. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a refrigerator

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport fish to sell

loans.name: Tserennadmid

texts.en: Tserennadmid J. is a 45 year old married woman with four children. She lives with her husband and four children in Huvsgul province of Mongolia, in their own ger, a traditional nomadic housing tent. Her oldest two children, aged 20 and 22, are students while her youngest two children, 12 and 16, attend a local school. Her husband works as a private businessman. Tserennadmid operates an electric appliances retail business in her town. She has been engaged this business since 2000, selling a variety of small household electrical goods in a rented stall at a local market. In the future, she hopes to have her own stall. She is a very modest and hardworking businesswoman and is requesting an 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to increase her working capital for her household electric appliances trading business.

loans.use: To buy more electrical goods.

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan L., 26, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. L. is a housewife while her husband is a laundry supervisor at a hotel in the town, earning an income of USD 220 per month. L. is requesting a loan of USD 750 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband to commute to work.

loans.name: Mihirbanum's Group

texts.en:
Mihirbanum B. is the leader of the group. She is 41 and she is married. With her husband, who works as a gas welder, they are parents of 3 children (a daughter and 2 sons). Two of the children are students, the junior one goes to kindergarten. For three years already, with the help of her friend, Mihirbanum has earned a living by selling fruits in the market. Today, this family's mother earns additionally by providing manicure and hairdressing services. At this point, with the help of their earnings, they have managed to obtain domestic appliances and to do partial house repairs. The family needs a loan in order to buy vegetables (potatoes, tomatoes, cucumbers) to resell and to prepare canned stores for winter. In future Mihirbanum wishes to give a good education to her children, to give them a proper upbringing, to buy a new car and to open her own beauty shop.

Antonina K., 29, divorced. She is a treasurer of this group. By herself, she is bringing up a daughter. This unwed mother earns her livelihood by working as an operator in a playing club. The loan purpose is to buy building materials in order to finish house repairs. Antonina wants to marry, give birth to more children and to buy a car. 

Rustam K., 22, a bachelor. He works in “Abdysh-ata” company as a loader as well as in a military part of a boiler-house. His additional income comes from cattle breeding. He decided to start this business after having helped his friend in doing it. His mother helps him to run this business. During these years he has managed to purchase some household appliances. Rustam needs a loan in order to buy two calves for further fattening and to increase stock. Planning his future, Rustam wants to build a big house, to marry and to buy a car.  

Ainagul S., 58, is divorced. She has an adult son, who works in OsOO Abdysh-Ata as a common worker. Ainagul makes her living by working as an ambulance medical assistant. The loan purpose is to buy wallpaper and a chandelier in order to decorate a hall. In the future she wants to arrange her son’s wedding, to buy a flat and a car. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables.

loans.name: Eon

texts.en: The person in the photo is Mrs. Eon R., age 31, who has been spending her life cultivating crops. Eon R. has known this skill since she was single. She is now married and has three young kids. Two of her kids are enrolled in school and the other one stays at home. Eon R. also receives help from her husband who works in the farm fields frequently alongside her. Growing crops is an annual action with which she has had great success. Eon R. desires to plant potatoes and peanut crops on her own farmland during this approaching farming season and is asking for a loan to be used to purchase items such as fertilizer, insecticide, and seeds to begin growing.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, insecticides, and seeds to begin growing.

loans.name: Angelito

texts.en:
Angelito B. is from the village of Larion Bajo, Tuguegarao City. He is 43 years old. Angelito is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Angelito owns & operates a business selling kitchen supplies & products to local community members. Angelito has been engaged in his business for over 12 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Angelito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Angelito is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Angelito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to his house. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Farida

texts.ru:
Farida R. 43 qoda. Ona zamujem i imeyet 4 detey starshaya doch kotoroy 20 let ona pomoqayet mame po domashnim rabotam, sin 18 let v etom qodu postupil v universitet , dochka 16 let ona uchitsya v shkole i pomoqayet inoqda mame po rabote, i dochka 14 let toje uchitsya v shkole. Farida i yeyo semya jivut v Absheron regione. 

Farida uje 7 let kak zanimayetsya etim biznessom prodaji pasudi, Etomu biznesu ona naushilas u svoyey teti. Seychas Farida nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi sdelat remont pomesheniya i rasshirit yeqo.
texts.en:
Farida R. is 43 years old. She is married and has four children. Her twenty-year-old daughter helps he mother with the housework. Her son is eighteen and entered the university this year. Her sixteen-year-old daughter goes to school and sometimes helps her mother in the business, and her fourteen-year-old daughter goes to school as well. Farida and her family live in the Absheron region. Farida has been working selling dishes for seven years. She started this business with her aunt. Now, Farida needs 2000 AZN to renovate and expand her shop.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To renovate and expand her shop

loans.name: Peter Macharia

texts.en:
Peter has been in the motorcycle transport business since 2008. He is 26 years old, married to Jane Wambui and they have one child.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan. He paid off his first loan well and on time. He plans to use this cash to buy a used motorbike. He will employ someone else to run the motorbike for him. This will increase his income.

Peter is planning to buy a taxi in the near future.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike.

loans.name: Joseph Guthonda

texts.en:
Joseph has been operating his taxi in Naivasha town for the last three years now.  He is 31 years old, married to Beth Muthoni and they have one child.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friend and this will be his second loan. He paid off his first loan well and on time. He is planning to use the loan amount as top up to his savings and to buy a new taxi.

Joseph plans to buy a minibus in future which he will use for public transport.

loans.use: To top up and buy a new taxi.

loans.name: Nai

texts.en: Nai K., 45, is married and resides with his wife and six children in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. K. is a traditional musician, earning an income of USD 10 per day. K. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a motorbike to take his family members to play music at the night market in the town. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house. This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport his family members to play traditional music.

loans.name: Kunduz's Group

texts.en:
Kunduz T. 20, is not married yet. She is the leader of the group. The family funds are enriched with the help of herself and her parents working. They breed cattle. Kunduz makes an income by selling bottles. The very first salary gave her an opportunity to buy two sheep. She needs a loan in order to buy a calf. In the future she wants to increase cattle stock.

Azat N., 24, is a bachelor. Together with his brother, they have stayed in their homeland, whereas their parents went to Russia. Today Azat is a casino security guard in Bishkek. He has managed to achieve some results: he has equipped his house. Besides his basic job, the young man is earning money additionally by cattle breeding. He needs a loan in order to buy a calf. In future he is planning to increase his cattle stock.

Gulperi N., 20, is not married. She works in a company “Abdysh-ata”, which produces bottles. Four years ago her parents had presented her with a calf. Since that time, she has been breeding cattle. The loan purpose is to buy one more calf for increasing stock. 

Aziza K., 23, is not married. She earns her livelihood by working in a privately owned enterprise, which sells coffee. Last year she received money (5000 soms ) as a birthday gift from her parents. She bought a sheep and since that has been breeding cattle. Her brother has helped her to run her small business. Out of the proceeds she has managed to buy some household appliances. The loan purpose is to buy a calf. Aziza wants to increase cattle stock. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf.

loans.name: Margaret Mugure

texts.en:
Margaret has been selling fruits and vegetables in Naivasha town for the past six years. She is 26 years old, married to James Ngang'a and they have one child.  

She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend and this will be her second loan. She paid her first loan well and in good time. She is planning to diversify and start selling cereals, which include green grammes (mung beans), peas, rice, maize and beans. She will use the loan amount to buy the cereals in large quantities.

Margaret hopes to build a shop, in future, from which she will be selling her products.

loans.use: To buy cereals to sell.

loans.name: Tourn

texts.en: Tourn H., 49, is married and resides with his wife and a child in Seim Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean Temples. H. is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 7.5 per day. His wife sells fish and vegetables for an income of USD 12 per day. H. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a new motorbike to attach to a tuk tuk to improve his transportation business. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a new motobike to attach to a tuk tuk

loans.name: Iman

texts.en:
Iman A. L. is a young woman from Rafah city, her father owns a Taxi car that transfers passengers between Rafah and Gaza City, Iman's father has been in this profession for 10 years now, as its the only source of income for the family Iman came to FATEN to take a $2,000 loan so that her father could do maintenance the car needs.

Iamn's father drives for long hours everyday between the two cities in Gaza Strip and needs a strong car for such purpose, and as it's the only source of income for the family it needs to remain in a good shape.
Iamn's father appears in the picture here next to the car, since Iman refused to be photographed for social reasons and explained that she is not the one driving the car.

loans.use: Car maintenance

loans.name: Phillis Nyambura

texts.en: Phyllis, who is 38 years old, married to W. Ngigi, and the mother of four children, has been practicing small scale farming in Naivasha town for the last two years. She was introduced to KADET LTD by her friend, and this will be her first loan with which she plans to plough her farm and buy bean seedlings to plant.  In order to increase her produce and income, Phyllis is planning to start planting different types of crops in the near future

loans.use: To buy bean seedlings for planting.

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en: Batjargal C., who is 44 years old, lives with his wife and two children in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent, in Huvsgul province of Mongolia.   His oldest daughter is a student and his youngest son attends a local secondary school. His wife operates a grocery business, selling a variety of food products at her pavilion in a local market. Batjargal operates a taxi service in his town, an enterprise he began in 2002, and has gained many years of experience.  A very modest, open-minded and hardworking person, he is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan in order to improve the car that he uses as a taxi.

loans.use: To improve his car

loans.name: Ulmas

texts.ru: Хонтураева Улмас проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 41 год. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Муж, работает плотником. Сама Улмас имеет среднее образование. Она вместе с мужем занимается бизнесом.  Её муж изготавливает люльки и ходунки, а она продает оптом. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 5 лет. Кредит берет для покупки материала, т.е. для закупа рейки, ДСП, и ДВП для изготовления.
texts.en:
Ulmas K. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. She is 41 years old, married, and has three children. Her husband works as a carpenter. Ulmas has a high school education. She and her husband work together in their business. Her husband makes cradles and baby walkers, and she sells them wholesale. They have been doing this for more than five years. She is taking out a loan to buy materials such as rails, particleboard, and fiberboard for manufacturing.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying production materials

loans.name: Daniel Changwony

texts.en: Daniel, who has been practicing livestock farming for six years now, is 32 years old, married to Nancy Chepkemoi, and the father of three children.   Introduced to KADET LTD by his friend, he is now requesting his first loan with which he plans to buy more cows and sheep which he will rear and later sell at a profit.  Daniel hopes to own a big animal farm in the future and become a major supplier of animal products in Naivasha town and the surrounding area.

loans.use: To buy sheep and cows which he will rear and later sell

loans.name: Wendelyn

texts.en:
Wendelyn T., from the village of Tabon, is 42 years old, married, and has six children. To make a living, Wendelyn owns and operates a general store selling a variety of products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years, she earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Wendelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Now requesting her first loan of 3000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell, she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Batmolom

texts.en:
Batmolom D. is a 44-year-old married man with three children. His oldest two daughters attend university while his youngest child attends a local high school. His family lives in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent in the province of Huvsgul in Mongolia. His wife operates a construction material trading business in a container at a local construction market while Batmolom runs a household electrical appliances shop at a stall in his town.

Batmolom and his wife have been selling construction materials since 2000 and have since expanded their business by increasing their product line. Both his and his wife’s businesses have enabled them to improve the family’s quality of life. Over the years of successful operation, Batmolom has been able to pay his children's tuition fees. Batmolom is requesting an 2,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase a variety of spare auto parts for his shop.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of spare auto parts

loans.name: Samuel Mwangi

texts.en:
Samuel Mwangi K. is 42 years old, married to Priscah Wanjiku and has four children who attend school.

Samuel started commercial farming last year. He was introduced to KADET by his friend. This will be his first loan. He plans to use the cash to plow his farm, buy maize seedlings and plant them.

Samuel is hoping to expand his farm and also to open a grocery shop in the future.

loans.use: To plow his farm and buy maize seedlings

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.en:
Maria Luisa A. is 43 years old, married and has three school-aged children. She is from the village of Larion Bajo, Tuguegarao City on the islands of Luzon. Maria Luisa runs a shop from which she sells a variety of different products to the local community. Maria Luisa has been engaged in her business for over eight years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Maria Luisa joined ASKI to gain access to its financial services. Maria Luisa is requesting a loan, her first from ASKI, of 5000 PHP that will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About ASKI:

Alalay sa Kaunlaran, Inc., or ASKI, is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and -women, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that one-on-one translations of entrepreneur profiles are costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow it to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Karen

texts.en:
Karen N. was born in 1987. He lives in Ijevan city with his family. After graduating from Yerevan State University’s Ijevan branch, Karen works at Tavush Construction LLC as an accountant. 

Since 2007, Karen and his family have engaged in beekeeping. Thanks to the income from beekeeping, Karen paid for his education and bought furniture for his house. He says his business is very hard, but at the same time it is very interesting for him. 
  
Now Karen seeks a loan of 900.000 Armenian Drams to buy 15 beehives for his business.

loans.use: To buy 15 beehives for his business

loans.name: Chinbat

texts.en:
Chinbat R. is a modest, open-minded man. He is 31 and lives with his wife and son in Huvsgul province, Mongolia, in their own fenced ger, a traditional Mongolian housing tent. His son, Batzolboo, attends a local secondary school while his wife is currently unemployed.

Chinbat has been operating a mobile phone business in a rented store space for ten years and now has some clients. He purchases mobile phones and tools by himself. He hired his sibling as a salesperson at his stall.

Chinbat wishes to expand the business and own his shop. He is requesting a 3,600,000 MNT loan to purchase mobile phones and spare parts in order increase his sales.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phones and spare parts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more bales of used clothing and drums of palm oil

loans.name: Adikalie

texts.en:
Alikalie is 29 years old, married and has three children aged five, four and three years. He has two additional dependents, his younger brothers, who live with him because Alikalie is the only one who can take care of them.

In 2005 Alikalie established his soft drinks, provisions, biscuits and cigarette business. He began his business because he dropped out of school and found business to be his only alternative. Working seven days a week and fifteen hours a day, he earns about 1,471,200 SLL every month.

Alikalie would like a loan in the amount of 4,500,000 SLL. Alikalie requires a loan in order to buy more provisions. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 367,800 SLL. In the future Alikalie plans to purchase a popcorn machine. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more products for his shop

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Mrs. Pov P. has had a farming job for many years. She owns a piece of land where she plants various crops from which she always gets an income to serve the needs of her family. Pov P. has a life partner who works with her at the farm, and they have four children: one child is already married and the other three are single. 

Pov P. wishes to invest in another business. Through this new business, she believes she will be able to generate extra income to ensure that her family attains a better standard of living. Because she lacks money to use as capital, Pov P. has requested a loan from Kiva’s project partner so she can buy salt and fish paste to resell.

loans.use: To buy salt and fish paste

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en:
Dorcas is a 39 year-old single mother of six children (Kiprotich 16, Kipchirchir 14, Kostany 12, Jebet 10, Kichumba 6, and Jepngetich 4). Dorcas runs a kiosk that she started five years ago. This business gives her a monthly profit of 5,000 KES. 

This loan of 15,000 KES is Dorcas' first loan from KADET LTD.  She plans to use 7,000 KES to buy two bags of sugar, 5,000 KES to buy five boxes of tea leaves, and 3,000 KES to buy two boxes of bar soap. Dorcas intends to use the profits to expand her business. Her dreams and hopes are to have a big business and be able to meet the financial needs of her family.

loans.use: To purchase stock

loans.name: Dulamragchaa

texts.en:
Dulamragchaa D. is 42 years old and lives with his wife and two teenage sons in their ger (a traditional housing tent) in Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. Both sons, ages 16 and 14, attend a local high school. His wife has been operating a construction business specializing in interior decorating since 1990 and has built a stable operation. 

From 2000 to 2009, Dulamragchaa operated a taxi service using his own car. In 2009, based on his wife's experience, he started selling plumbing supplies in a small pavilion. In the future, he plans to open his own construction store. He is a very hardworking man. He is requesting a 1,050,000 MNT loan to purchase a large number of plumbing supplies.

loans.use: To purchase plumbing supplies

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchasing thread, scissors, and so on

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
This is 52 year-old Mohamed. He is married and has five children (aged 27, 21, 17, and 8 year-old twins). He has three additional dependents who live with him because they came for education since there is no opportunity for education in the village.  

In 1985, Mohamed established his bread business as a means to support his family. Working 7 days a week and 12 hours a day, he earns about 1,379,000SLL every month. He would like a loan of 4,000,000SLL. Mohamed needs the loan to buy more bags of bread flour. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 206,850SLL. 

In the future, Mohamed plans to give his wife some capital to start a new business. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase bread flour

loans.name: Kadie

texts.en: This is 38-year-old Kadie. She is married and has two children who are 22 and 19 years old. She has one additional dependent who lives with her: her younger brother. He also helps her run her business. In 1999, Kadie established her business selling kitchenware such as pans, bowls, spoons, etc. Her mother taught her that her business is her career. Many of Kadie’s customers live in rural areas. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, Kadie earns about 2,930,000 SLL every month from her business. Kadie needs a loan of 4,500,000 SLL in order to buy large quantities of products for resale (e.g., drinking cups, sets of bowls, etc.) She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 439,500 SLL. Kadie intends to use the proceeds from this loan to educate her children through school and university. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more kitchenware

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary K. is 47 years old and married to Haron Bunei. They have been blessed with seven children: Kipkorir (26 years old), Josephine (24), Anette (22), Faith (19), Erick (17), Carolyne (15), and Kipchumba (13).

Mary runs a kiosk where she sells products like sugar, rice, tea leaves, and salt in small quantities. Her business gives her an average profit of KES 1,000 per month, which she uses to help her husband support their family. Mary started this business three years ago and hopes that the business will grow with a loan from KADET LTD.
 
She has borrowed KES 5,000 for her first loan with KADET LTD. She intends to use the money to buy products for resale: KES 3,500 to buy sugar and KES 1,500 to buy tea leaves. Mary will use the profits from the business to expand the business and also to pay school fees for her children. Her hope is to expand her business to eventually sell products wholesale and to be able to employ people in her business. She also hopes to be able to fully meet the needs of her family members.

loans.use: To purchase products for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchasing sewing materials

loans.name: Meach

texts.en: Meach P. is 54 years old and lives with three children in the Kampong Chhnang province. She is a widow and has a business weaving mats to sell at the local market. She has been operating this business since 2000 and is able to make about $1 US of profit a day. She is also supported by her children who are workers. This family spends $40 on food, $20 on transportation, and $10 on other expense. Meach P. is asking for a loan of $400 to purchase cows to plow farmland. (Meach P. is pictured with her son from home.)

loans.use: To purchase cows to plow farmland.

loans.name: Yealie

texts.en:
This is 47-year-old Yealie.  She is married and has 3 children aged 32, 28 and 24. She has four additional dependents who live with her because they are relatives of her husband who helps them at home and sends them to school.  

In 1985, Yealie established her rubber bucket, bowl, baskets, and plates business. She began her business because her parents taught her trading since she did not go to school.  Working 7 days a week and 9 hours a day, she earns about 2,650,000 Sierra Leonean leones (SLL) every month from this business. She needs a loan of 4,500,000 SLL.  

Yealie requires a loan in order to purchase more market basket, washing boards, rubber kettles, and sets of pans for resale. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 715,500 SLL. In the future, Yealie plans to make plenty of money to help her husband support their children and improve their business. Yealie is selling in the middle of her competitors but her communication skills and customer care helps her a lot.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy household items for resale

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en: Sorn S., 37, is married and lives with her husband and her one child in the Kampong Chhnang province. She is employed at the local organization with a salary of US $150 per month. Her husband grows and sells plants. On average, he makes $1 a day. Since the house has difficulty during the rainy season, Sorn S. would like to take out a loan of $500 to fix her leaking roof.

loans.use: To fix her leaking roof.

loans.name: Kenneth Aroka

texts.en:
Kenneth is single and has no children yet.

Kenneth is requesting his second loan in KADET LTD and has no other loans with other MFIs. He serves in a middle class estate and it is well populated. 

Kenneth will use the extra profits to open a new laboratory, Kenneth hopes to have many laboratory branches.

Kenneth describes himself as hard working and social.

loans.use: purchasing a blood test machine

loans.name: Him

texts.en: Him M., 46, is a widow and lives with three children in the Kampong Chhnang province. She works in a grocery store, typically making $2 US of profit a day. She is also supported by one child who works as a garment factory worker. Him M. is asking for a loan of $300 to increase her stock of grocery items.

loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Sokinamo

texts.ru: Ширинова Сокинамо проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 42 года. Разведена, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается торговлей на рынке. Она в основном готовить разные блюда и продает. Этим видом деятельности занимается более 10 лет. Кредит берет для приобретения продуктов питания. Полученную прибыль она хочет вложить в другой бизнес.
texts.en:
Sokinamo S. lives in the city of Kulob. She is 42 years old, divorced, and has four children. She has a high school education. She works trading in the market. She prepares and sells different dishes. She has been doing this work for more than ten years. She is taking out a loan to buy foodstuffs. She wants to use this money for another business.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying foodstufs

loans.name: Theng

texts.en:
Mrs. S. (her husband is pictured) is 26 and currently lives with other family members in the province of Kompong Chhnang. She is a domestic farmer and also arranges a daily routine, including cooking and caring for kids. 

S. also relies on the income from her husband who has been operating an animal trade in the village. He always travels to buy cows from rural people and he then fattens the cows for a while before selling them to raise a profit. 

This couple attempts to work for money in order to support their two kids who are in primary school. Mrs. S. sees that the animal sale business is a profitable one and she wants to sustain its growth, this is why she requested a loan from Kiva. She will provide this loan to her husband for use as capital to buy animals to resell.

loans.use: To buy animals to resell.

loans.name: Gbiril

texts.en:
This is 57-year-old Gibril.  He is married and has four children who are all adults living independent lives. He has seven additional dependents, who live with him because they are his relatives and he is the eldest in his family.  

In 2007, Gibril established a cinema, sports, and games business. He began his business after he retired from his job. He started this business because he needed to find a new way of earning a living.  Working 3 days a week and 4 hours a day, he earns about 1,248,000 Sierra Leonean leones (SLL) every month from this business. He would like a loan 3,000,000 SLL. Gibril requires a loan in order to buy a satellite dish and decoder. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 249,600 SLL. In the future, Gibril plans to expand the cinema space, get new satellite channels, and open a new business for his wife. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy sports and games items

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: expanding store inventory

loans.name: Bou

texts.en: Bou N. lives with her husband in the Kampong Chhnang province. She is a good housewife stays at home and takes care her children. Her husband has a business operating a moto-taxi, and he is able to make about $7 US in revenue each day. This couple has three children; one is in school, while the other two are too young to attend. Bou N. is asking for a loan of $1200 to purchase a motorbike with a trailer attached for her husband's moto-taxi business.

loans.use: purchasing a motorbike with trailer for use as a taxi

loans.name: Shuru's Group

texts.en:
Shuru S., the leader of the group, is 56, married, and has raised two sons and four daughters, most of whom are married and living separately with their families. Their youngest son lives with them and helps with housework. Shuru and her husband are pensioners engaged in cattle breeding. Selling the cattle after fattening them, they make money to cover their family expenses. With money received from the loan, Shuru wants to purchase a calf for breeding.

Surma S., the treasurer of the group, is a 48-year-old married mother of two sons and a daughter, all employed. Surma works as a teacher of chemistry at school and her husband is a farmer engaged in cattle breeding. Surma applied for the loan because she wants to purchase a cow in order to increase their number of cattle. In the future she wants to see her sons get married.

Anarhan A., 42 and married, has a nine-year-old daughter attending school. Anarhan and her husband work in a factory, and with the money received from the loan, she wants to purchase a washing machine in order to improve their living conditions. In the future they are planning to purchase a vehicle.

Aliza U. is 22. Five years ago, after an initial investment of 15000 soms, her parents built a store. Aliza now sells convenience goods in that store, earning 25000 soms per month. She hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase more goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future she wants to save money and purchase a vehicle.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a calf

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en: Pauline W. is 35 years old. She is single and has one child, aged eight years old. Her business is located in Juja, in a residential area in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for the production of pineapples. Pauline sells assorted items which include sweets, paraffin, charcoal and others. She has been in this business for the last 15 years. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that there are many people in the area with the same kind of business as hers; hence, customers are spoilt by the choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more paraffin and charcoal to expand her business. In the future, she hopes to buy a pick-up for car rental. She is a very hardworking and humble lady.

loans.use: To buy paraffin and charcoal

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy essential materials

loans.name: Kemokai

texts.en:
This is 43-year-old M.. He is married and has two children, ages 10 and 5 years. He has two additional dependents who live with him because they are his sisters-in-law. In the year 2000, M. established a hard rum, soft drinks, engine oil and water business. He started this on a small scale then developed it from the proceeds raised. Working 6 days a week and 9 hours a day, he earns about 2,708,000 leones (SLL) every month from this business. 

M. has a very good loan repayment history. He needs a loan of 4,500,000 SLL. M. has already received and successfully repaid a loan of 3,000,000 and now requires a new loan in order to buy bitter appetizer, bumper gin, pure heaven and bull gin. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 812,400 SLL. M. hope to reinvest the proceeds from this loan into his business and educate his children. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for his stall

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice N. is 24 years old. She is single and has one child aged seven years old. Her business is located in Juja, a residential area in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. Eunice sells fruits and vegetables to retail traders and other local people. She has been in this business for the last four years and has managed to get two employees. She says that this business is profitable and her major challenge is lack of finances. However, she works very hard from early morning to late evening to keep her business doing well. 

Eunice is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more melons which she can supply wholesale. In the future, she hopes to be able to supply fruits and vegetables to other markets. She also hopes to purchase her own plot of land and build rental houses. She describes herself as social, honest and hardworking.

loans.use: To buy melons

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 29-year-old married woman and the mother of one young child. In 2008, she decided to open a clothes store after having her baby, to help her husband with the new expenses. She is thankful for her decision because, with her business income, she is able to support her husband well. And now, she is waiting for her second baby and she is asking for a loan of $1000 from Kiva's partner, Ameen s.a.l., to expand her store’s inventory. She says that the loan will help her diversify her merchandise selection and make more profit for her family. In the future, she is hoping to also sell shoes from her store. Currently, she mostly sells clothes.

loans.use: To expand her store’s inventory

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria E. is a 66-year-old farmer. She is married and has five children. Her affectionate husband, Jasasyn, has been a tower of strength to her for almost 40 years. Cattle breeding is the only source of subsistence for this couple. They began this business in 1995, starting with the purchase of one milk cow. Today they have a small farm with milk cows and earn about 3,500 soms (KGS) monthly by selling milk.

Maria and her husband concentrate all their efforts on supporting and expanding their household. For this very reason, Maria wants to take a loan of 60,000 KGS to buy bull calves for fattening and reselling. With the revenue from this investment, she plans to develop her farm by means of livestock breeding. In the future, Maria dreams that her grandson will keep on with the farm and become an efficient farmer.

Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target an especially vulnerable population. Bai-Tushum and Partners is one of the leading Microfinance Institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, Bai-Tushum contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 46 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Djinina, sous préfecture de Fana, région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce de charbon de bois, d’habillements et des articles divers.
Ces femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur treizième prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursés les douze précédents.                                                                                        
FATOUMATA T. du groupe Benkadi compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des habits pour enfants et femmes.
Elle s’approvisionne le plus généralement au marché de Fana et à Bamako et effectue sa vente au village et au bord du goudron, au comptant, en gros et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 12.500FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi group, all married, are on average 46 years old, with 4 children, and all live in traditional families in the village of Djinina, under jurisdiction of Fana, in the region of Koulikoro (second administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They know each other through family and community links, and are all involved in selling wood, clothes and other diverse products. These women are asking for their thirteenth loan, after having reimbursed their previous loans in a timely manner. Ms. Fatoumata T. of the Benkadi group plans to use her loan to purchase clothing for children and women. She generally stocks up on products at the markets in Fana and Bamako and sells to both men and women in her village and on the side of the paved roads, asking for credit or cash. She hopes to make a profit of approximately 12,500 CFA a month (25 USD), to be spent on daily family expenses and reinvested into her business activities.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing clothes

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan W. is 27 years old. She is single and has one child, age eight years old. Her business is located in Juja, a busy area in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for the production of pineapples. Susan sells fruits and vegetables to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and her only major challenge is slow business in some seasons. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

Susan is using her loan of 15,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more fruits and vegetables to expand her business. In the future, she hopes to become a supplier of fruits and vegetables and also buy a plot of land to build her own house. She describes herself as a very hardworking lady.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Materials for her tailoring

loans.name: Carolyne

texts.en:
Carolyne M. K. is 28 years old and married. Her husband is a casual laborer and they have three children aged between 9 and 13 whom they hope to educate to the university level. 

Her business is located in Mwingi but served by the Thika Branch. Thika is the region in Kenya known for the production of pineapples. She has been selling goats to the local people for the last 10 years. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is getting food for the goats during the dry season and actually, some goats die during this period. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more goats to meet her customers' demand. She sees herself selling goats wholesale in Mwingi and other towns in Kenya. She describes herself as hardworking, courageous and social.

loans.use: To buy more goats

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchasing vegetables and fruits

loans.name: Anastacia

texts.en:
Anastacia K. is 43 years old and married. Her husband is a constructor and they have seven children aged between 2 and 29 whom they hope to educate to the university level. Her business is located in Mwingi but served by the Thika Branch. Thika is the region in Kenya known for the production of pineapples. 

She has been selling goats to the local people for the last three years. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is getting food for the goats during the dry season and actually, some goats die during this period. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more goats to meet her customers' demand. She sees diversifying the business to cereals in the future. She describes herself as hardworking, social and responsible.

loans.use: To buy more goats

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkan, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 45 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Djinina, sous préfecture de Fana, région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce d’habits de tous genres, du charbon de bois, du bois de chauffe, de céréales et des beignets à base de haricot et de mil.                                                                                                             
Ces femmes du groupe Benkan sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire, après avoie bien remboursés les deux prêts précédents.                                                                                        
DJOULE S. du groupe Benkan compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des habits pour toutes catégories de personnes.
Elle s’approvisionne essentiellement à Bamako et effectue sa vente au village et au marché de Fana, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group named Benkan are all married and on average they are 45 years old and have 2 children. They all live in large traditional families in the village of Djinina in the Fana and Koulikoro region (the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are known through family and neighbours and they sell clothing, wood coal, firewood, cereal grains and baked donuts. The women of the Benkan group are on their third loan cycle, following having successfully repaid two past loans. Djoule S. of the Benkan group plans on using her loan to purchase clothing of all kinds. She makes her purchases in Bamako for later resale in the market in Fana. She completes her sales in cash and credit to a clientele made up of both women and men. She forsees having a monthly income of 15 FCFA and it will be used to cover the daily expenses for the family adn the rest will be reinvested back into the business.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothing.

loans.name: Alie

texts.en:
This is 39 year-old F.. He is single and has one child, aged 10 years. He has seven additional dependents who live with him because they are his younger brothers and sisters. He must look after them since their father is now an old man.

In 2006, F. established his business selling paints, cigarettes, pure water, rum and soft drinks. He started this business with a very small amount of capital. He started with a table in a market and after some time, he was able to accumulate enough money and capital and then opened a shop.  

Working seven days a week and eight hours a day, he earns about 800,400 Sierra Leone leones (SLL) every month from this business. He would like a loan of 3,000,000SLL. F. requires a loan in order to buy rum, cigarettes and pure water in large quantities for resale. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 200,000SLL. In the future, F. plans to build a bigger shop. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase more stock

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica W. is 29 years old. She is married and has two children, aged 4 and 7 years. Her business is located at Juja in Thika. Thika is the region in Kenya known for the production of pineapples. 

She sells fruits and vegetables, including oranges and pineapples. She also sells sweet potatoes and arrow roots. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that there are very many people in the area doing the same kind of business as hers; hence, customers are spoiled for choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more fruits and vegetables to meet customer demand. In the future, she hopes to own her own premises from where she will be running her business. She describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: Fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Mr. Keo H. is a middle-aged man whose wife appears in the photo here. Keo H., age 38, is a low-income citizen living with other members in the Baray commune in the province of Kompong Tom. 

To generate a daily income, Keo H. owns a small trade of which the main activity is to make furniture to sell. He also saves up many sets of wooden beds and rattan cupboards before selling out. He transports the finished products directly to customers' houses. Recently, the essential raw material has been exhausted and he wants to resupply so he is seeking a loan to purchase materials in order to produce furniture.

loans.use: To purchase materials in order to produce furniture

loans.name: Djantoyerela Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djantoyerela, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 51 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Djinina, sous préfecture de Fana, région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce du charbon de bois d’habillements etc.                                                                                              
Ces femmes du groupe Djantoyerela sont à leur treizième prêt solidaire et tous les douze prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.                                                             
KADIA  T., la présidente du groupe Djantoyerela compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des sacs de charbon de bois
Elle s’approvisionne auprès des charbonniers du village et environnants et effectue sa vente au village et au bord du goudron et au marché de Fana, au comptant, en gros et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 75.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group named Djantoyerela are all married and on average they are 51 years old and have three children. They all lives in large traditional families in the village of Djinina in the Fana and Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are known through their families and through neighbours. They sell wood coal, clothing etc. The women of the Djantoyerela group are on their thirteenth loan cycle, having successfully repaid the twelve previous loans. Kadia T. is the leader of the Djantoyerela group. She will use her loan to purchase sacks of wood coal. She purchases the product from coal producers in the village and the surrounding regions and she resells in the village and along the tar pit and in the market in Fana. She completes her sales in cash, in wholesale, and in credit, to a clientele make up of men and women. She foresees a monthly income of 75 FCFA which will be used to cover the family's daily expenses and the rest will be reinvested back in the business.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wood coal.

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo sont toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 33 ans et 2 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Djinina, sous préfecture de Fana, région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce du bois de chauffe, de charbon de bois, de l’arachide et du riz.                                                                                                             
Ces femmes du groupe Djekafo sont à leur premier prêt solidaire.                                                                                        
SITAN S., qui est un des membres du groupe Djekafo compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter de l’arachide.
Elle s’approvisionne le plus généralement auprès des producteurs du village et effectue sa vente au village et au marché de Fana, aux transformation en pâte d’arachide, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 75 000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group named Djekafo are all married and on average they are 33 years old and have 2 chidlren. They live in large traditional families in the village of Djinina in the Fana and Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They are known through their family and through neighbours. They sell firewood, wood coal, peanuts and rice. This is a first time loan for the Djekafo group. Sitan S. is one of the members of the Djekafo group and she will use her loan to purchase peanuts. She usually purchases from the producers in the village and she resells in the village and in the market in Fana, after she makes peanut butter from the product. She completes her sales in cash and credit and she sells to a clientele made up of women and men. She foresees a monthly income of 75 FCFA which will be used to cover the family's daily expesnes and the rest will be reinvsted back in the business.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase peanuts.

loans.name: Amarjargal

texts.en:
Amarjargal S. is 34-year-old married woman with one daughter. She has been living with her husband and daughter in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia for 11 years. She and her family live in a "ger," a traditional Mongolian housing tent. Her husband works as a driver in the Umnugobi province while the daughter attends a local secondary school. 

Amarjargal operates a hair salon in her town with several business partners. They share the rent of a rented room to operate their salon. Oyuntsetseg started to work as a hairdresser in 2002 after graduating vocational training as a hairdresser in 2000. Since then, her business has grown steadily over the years and is a popular salon in the area. She was able to expand her business by purchasing a new chair and mirror for her salon in 2005. Over the years, all her equipment and tools have deteriorated due to long usage; therefore, she needs more funds to renew those items. She is a very accurate and optimistic person and is requesting a 2,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase necessary tools and equipment for her salon.

loans.use: To purchase necessary tools and equipment

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy necessary things for the shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Completing the things which are necessary for his drugstore

loans.name: Hanh's Group

texts.en:
Hanh T. N.  is 36 years old. She has two children who are attending high school. Being an experienced farmer, her main activities are growing rice and vegetables and raising pigs for meat. She has created daily income from selling these agricultural products for many years. Joining with our credit program in 2004, she  has used loans effectively in her business and repaid well. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 5,450,000 Vietnamese Dong (VND) to buy fertilizer and food for the pigs.

Hong T. N. is 39 years old. She has three children who are at both high school and secondary school. She is running a small restaurant that serves breakfast to the local residents. She wants to have a loan of 6,322,000 VND to invest in her business.

Dien T. N. is 36 years with two children who are in secondary school. She is building a new house. She needs 4,142,000 VND to buy more construction materials.

Tue T. D. is 44 years old with three children, two of whom are in high school. She is running a shop that sells bicycle parts to repair bicycles. Currently, she needs to have a loan of 5,014,000 VND to invest in her shop.

Son T. N. is 54 years old with three children. She is a farmer. Currently, she is raising pigs for meat and buffaloes. She wants to have a loan of 5,450,000 VND to invest  in buying food and a part of it to improve the house for them.
 
Hoan T. N. is 26 years old with two children who are still small. She is making protective gloves under the order of some factories. Currently, she wants to have a loan of 2,398,000 VND to buy cloth as a raw material.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Sarakognouman Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Sarakognouman sont toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 50 ans, 2 enfants et vivent dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Djinina, sous préfecture de Fana,  région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté de voisinage et font le commerce de charbon de bois, de lait  et de céréales.  Elles sont à leur treizième prêt solidaire. MAMINE T. du groupe Sarakognouman compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter une quantité importante de charbon de bois.
Elle s’approvisionne auprès des charbonniers du village, dans les environnants et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Fana, au comptant, en gros et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 100 000F CFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group named Sarakognouman are all married. On avarage they are 50 years old and they have 2 children each. They live in large traditional families in the village of Djinina in the Fana and Koulikoro region (second administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They are known through their family and through neighbours. They sell wood coal, milk, and cereal grains. They are on their thirteenth loan. Mamine T. of the Sarakognouman group will use her loan to purchase a large quantity of wood coal. She buys her product from the coal producers in the village and surrounding areas and she resells in the village and in the market in Fana. She completes her sales in case, in wholesale and in credit, to a clientele made up of women and men. She foresees a monthly earning of 100 FCFC which will be used to cover her family's daily expesnes and the rest will be reinvested back into the business.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase wood coal.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more food for the store

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchasing firewood and tools

loans.name: Kenjebu Chynybekova's Group

texts.en:
Kenjebu C. is the leader of this group. She is 48, married and has two daughters and two sons. The first son is in army, the second is at school and the daughters are married and live separately with their families. Ten years ago, with an initial investment of 10,000 KGS, Kenjebu opened a cafeteria. Now she makes 10,000 KGS per month. Her husband works as a driver and his monthly salary is 5,000 KGS. Having saved money, Kenjebu and her husband purchased a vehicle and repaired their house. With money received from this loan, Kenjebu wants to purchase convenience goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she wants to build a house for her sons. 
Venera A. is the treasurer of the group. She is 52, a widow and has raised three daughters and a son. Her first daughter is married and lives separately with her family, her second daughter and her son are working in Russia, and her youngest daughter is at school. Ten years ago, with an initial investment of 5,000 KGS, Venera started to breed cattle. By selling the cattle after fattening she makes 5,000 KGS per month. She hopes to obtain this loan because she needs money to start cultivating maize and sunflowers. In the future, she wants to see all her children get married.
Abdimajit A., 52, is married with three daughters and three sons. His sons and youngest daughter are students, and his other daughters are married and live separately with their families. In order to make money, Abdimajit provides a mechanic’s service and his wife sells milk. Abdimajit also cultivates wheat and sunflowers. With money received from this loan, he wants to hire labor for farming. In the future, he wants to purchase a piece of land and then start building a house for his sons.
