Adalat A., 52, is married. She has two sons and a daughter. All of her children are married and work in Russia. Sixteen years ago, with an initial investment of 7,000 KGS, Adalat started to sell flour on the market. In this way, she makes 8,000 KGS per month. This profit made it possible for her to purchase a vehicle for her husband, who now works as a private driver. Adalat has applied for this loan because she wants to purchase flour in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she wants to expand her business and improve her living conditions.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit:  www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at  www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase convenience goods

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Very hard-working M. Patrick has been operating an agro-produce sales business, with his main product as bananas from Bihasha Rukungiri, for a period of more than seven years. With nostalgia, this happily married father of five children recalls how his business basked in high profit returns at its onset. Times have changed, however, as the business now is in diminishing returns, earning him 200,000 Ugandan shillings, in sharp contrast to the previous earnings due season changes.

Patrick is no exception herein in terms of doing business. What he is looking forward to now is the prospect of enhancing his business by buying fertilizer and improving production of bananas and coffee, which he grows most. He has other income-generating activities like the sale of coffee. With the auspices of this loan, he will improve on business expansion and production through mulching the plantations. He hopes to improve his revenue and also make himself more able to meet his day today life family necessities.

loans.use: To purchase mulches and fertilizer for plantation input

loans.name: Tiessiri Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Tiessiri, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 41 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Djinina, sous préfecture de Fana,  région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali). Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et de voisinage et font le commerce d’articles divers et de beignets. Ces femmes du groupe Tiessiri sont à leur treizième prêt solidaire. 
KOUMBLE C. du groupe Tiessiri compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter une quantité importante de céréales pour la préparation des beignets. Elle s’approvisionne en céréales auprès des producteurs et revendeurs du village, dans les environnants et effectue sa vente sur place, au marché de Fana pendant les jours de foire, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 60.000FCFA qui sera utilisé dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the group named Tiessiri are all married and on average they are 41 years old and have 3 children. They live in large traditional families in the village of Djinina in the Fana and Koulikoro region (second administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They are known through their families and through neighbours. They sells various merchandise articles and fried pastries. The Tiessiri gropu is on their thirteenth loan cycle. Koumble C. is a member of the Tiessiri group and she will use her loan to purchase a large quantity of cereal grains to make fried pastries. She purchases cereal grains from the producers and resalers in the village and in the surrounding regions and she sells her products in the village and in the market in Fana on special fair days. She completes her sales in cash and credit to a clientele made up of both women and men. She foresees a monthly income of 50 FCFA which will be used to cover her family's daily expenses and the rest will be reinvested back into her business.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase cereal grains.

loans.name: Yoram

texts.en:
Hard-working K. Yoram has been operating an agro-produce sales business from Kataruka village, Rukungiri, for a period of more than 20 years. With nostalgia, this happily married father of five children recalls how his business basked in high profit returns at its onset. Times have changed, however, as the business now is in diminishing returns earning him 200,000 Ugandan shillings, in sharp contrast to the previous earnings due to season changes.

Yoram is no exceptional herein in terms of doing business. What he is looking forward to now is the prospect of enhancing his business by buying fertilizer and improving production of bananas and coffee, which he grows most. With the auspices of this loan, he will improve on business expansion and production through mulching the plantations. He hopes to improve his revenue and also make himself more able to meet his daily life family necessities.

loans.use: For the purchase of agriculture inputs like mulches and fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les six membres du groupe Benkadi sont toutes mariées dans des familles monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 34 ans, 5 enfants et habitent dans le quartier Pelengana sud de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de leurs activités génératrices de revenus dans le marché Château de Ségou. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce des poissons, de glace, de calebasses et de pagnes wax. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter leur fonds de commerce, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 7ème prêt solidaire.
Madame Kadia  Tébé est beaucoup connue et sollicité à Pelengana surtout pendant les périodes de mariage (début de la saison pluvieuse) pour la qualité de ses calebasses. 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 3 colis de calebasses (environ une centaine de calebasses). Elle se ravitaille en calebasses à Tonan et à Ségou avec les forains de Noumou Wêrê pour celles qui sont gravées.  La revente se fait au comptant  et à crédit et parfois sur commande, à domicile, au marché Château de Ségou et à Bamako à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Madame Kadia  Tébé espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité et épargner. 
Elle a pour objectif d’avoir un lot à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group named Benkadi are all married and live in monogamous families. On average they are 34 years old and have 5 children each. They live in the Pelengana South quarter in Segou (fourth administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They are known through their famililes and through their neighbours and from their businesses in the Chateau de Segou market. The members of the group sell fish, ice, gourds, and clothing. With the goal of increasing their earnings the members of the group decided to integrate with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner) and they are on their seventh loan cycle. Mrs. Kadia Tebe is well known and sought out in Pelengana, especially during the wedding season (at the beginning of the rainy season) for the quality of the gourds she sells. She will use her loan to purchase 3 packs of gourds (about one hundred grouds). She stocks up her supply of gourds in Tonan and in Segou and in the fields of Noumou Were, for those that are decorated. She completes her sales in cash and in credit, sometimes taking orders from private homes and in the market Chateau de Segoup and in Bamako. Her clientele is mostly made up of women. With the help of this loan Mrs. Kadia Tebe hopes to earn a monthly income of 30FCFC which will be used to reinvest back into her business and part will be placed in savings. Her goal is to purchase a plot of land to build a house.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase gourds.

loans.name: Sabali Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Sabali sont mariés majoritairement dans des familles polygames. Elles ont en moyenne 43 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent  Darsalam, un des quartiers de le ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers  leurs activités génératrices de revenus dans le marché Médine de Ségou. Les membres du groupe font le petit commerce de pagnes wax et de céréales. 
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce afin de satisfaire la demande de plus en plus croissante des clients, les membres du groupe ont décidé d’adhérer au programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elles sont à leur 9ème de prêt solidaire.
 Madame Koumba  O., la présidente du groupe qui s’est spécialisée dans la vente, au marché Médine de Ségou, du niébé est affectueusement  surnommée Chô – Koumba (c’est-à-dire Koumba niébé). 
Elle compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 300kg de niébé. Elle se ravitaille en niébé à Ségou avec les foraines des villages environnants au marché Médine.  La revente se fait au comptant et à crédit, à domicile et au marché de Médine Ségou en détail à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes. 
Madame Koumba  O. espère réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour être réinvesti dans l’activité, épargner et payer les frais scolaires des enfants.
texts.en:
The four members of the group named Sabali are married and most of them live in polygamous families. On average they are 43 years old and have 4 children each. They live in Darsalam, a quarter in the village of Segou (fourth administrative region in the Republic of Mali). They are known through their various businesses in the market of Medine in Segou. The members of this group sell clothing and cereal grains. With the goal of increasing their income and in order to satisfy the ever increase client deamnd, the members of the group integrated with Soro Yiriwaso (Kiva Field Partner). Currently they are on their ninth loan cycle. Mrs. Koumba Ongoiba is the leader of the group in the Medine market in Segou where she sells beans, warmly nicknamed Koumba beans. She will use her loan to purchase 300 kg of beans. In Segou she stocks her supply of beans in the surrounding villages in and in the market in Medine. She completes her sales in cash and in credit, selling to private homes but also in the market in Medine. Her clientele is mostly made up of women. With the help of this loan Mrs. Koumba Ongoiba hopes to see a monthly income of 35 FCFA which will be reinvested back and the business, part will be placed in savings, and it will also pay for her children's schooling.

Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase beans.

loans.name: Benson

texts.en:
M. Benson is a 41-year-old married father of seven boisterous school children. To shoulder his responsibility of providing for them, he has over the period of the last 15 years been operating a consumable items retail shop in Muhorro Trading centre, Kyenjojo alongside produce business with sales made out of groundnuts, maize and more. His business has not been without setbacks; since its beginning, he has had to bear with a myriad number of challenges, such as the lack of steady income inflows. However, his business has remained active because of his hard-working traits and good customer relations. This principally he attributes to the good working chord he has struck with his clientele.

In a month, Benson says he makes 300,000 Ugandan shillings, a figure he admits will substantively make his business see the light of near future. He is therefore seeking a loan to lend countenance to his business so that he is able to do restocking for his shop as he looks at substantial growth.

loans.use: For business restocking

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: The Kiva borrower is a 30-year-old married man with one child. He is from Lebanon. He has been working as baker for more than seven years. His freshly prepared goods are enjoyed by members of his village and neighboring towns. With his requested loan of $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., he will purchase a new oven to further develop his shop and increase his productivity. He is planning to continue expansion of his business and he is positive about the coming year. His bakery is an important source of income for his family. Lebanon has many pastry shop and bakeries and it is easy to buy fresh goods in one’s village or neighborhood.

loans.use: To purchase a new oven

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase cotton and cloth

loans.name: Zakhir

texts.ru:
Zakhir M. 32 qoda. On ne jenat. On imeyet 2 sester kotoriye mladshe neqo poetomu on rabotaya pomoqayet semye.
Uje 8 let kak Zakir zanimayetsya etim biznessom rimonta i stroitelstva damov. Etomu biznesu on nauchilsya u svoyeqo otca kotoriy s molodix let toje rabotal masterom no seychas on uje boleyet i ne v silax rabotat.

Zakir seychas nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit instrumenti dlya razvitiya svoyeqo biznessa.
texts.en:
Zakhir M. is 32 years old and single. He has two younger sisters, and therefore he works to help his family. Zakhir has been working in is construction and renovation business for eight years. He started this business with his father, who also worked in construction from a young age. However, now his father is ill and no longer has the strength to work. Zakhir Now needs 2000 AZN to buy tools to expand his business.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying tools

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en:
Mahmoud is a young man from Palestine, he is married and has no children yet. Mahmoud is a Palestinian National Authority employee and a technician. Mahmoud owns a workshop where he fixes and does maintenance to electrical engines. Where Mahmoud lives, electricity cut off a lot which increases demand for his services.

Mahmoud came to FATEN to ask for a $1,000 loan to buy engines spare parts that he needs in his job. Mahmoud hopes to have a better life conditions and improve his life financially besides being able to have a bigger workshop and employee more technicians.

Mahmoud is fixing an engine in the picture here.

loans.use: Electronics engines maintenance

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more car parts for her husband's shop

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Hard-working, dependable, die-hard agriculturalist N. Henry, 42, has been maintaining a banana plantation and a coffee plantation for more than 10 years in his home area of Nyamubugore, Rukungiri. He earns an average of 100,000 Ugandan shillings per month from banana sales. However, this is not enough to sustain his family of 4 children as some of them are still students at different colleges.

Henry has persevered to keep the enterprise growing. He wants this loan to buy mulch and manure for his plantations as part of his expansion plan to sell his products to a bigger market. This will help him to increase productivity and to earn more revenue. He will then be able to have a more sustainable life.

loans.use: to buy mulch and other agricultural inputs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase construction supplies

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice N. is 21 years old and lives in the town of Natete in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has 2 children who both currently attend school. She has been running a business selling matooke (green plaintain) for 5 years.         

To help expand her business, Alice has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase matooke.  With the help of the loan, Alice hopes to generate greater profits and to buy food. In the future, Alice hopes to own a house.        

Alice is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by learning more about financial literacy.

loans.use: to but more matooke

loans.name: Kisa Development Group-Mukono

texts.en: She started off by selling firewood and charcoal before she branched off into her current clothes and food businesses that are now 20 years. 42-year-old M. Hasifa belongs to Kisa development group Mukono. The happily married mother of six says her customers also cut across the board from the lowest common denominators to middle class people who live within the vicinity of Kalagi, her operating area. In a month, she says, she makes 200,000 shillings and with this loan, this hard working lady says she wants to buy more bales of clothes to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more bales of clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy construction materials

loans.name: Devine Grace Development-Mukono Group

texts.en: 39 year old M. Jane belongs to Devine grace group-Mukono. She has been operating her flower selling business in Kireka-Kampala for the past 4 years. She was prevailed upon to run this business by her husband of 12 years. Her customers range from middle to low class income earners. Her first business was selling clothes. In a week, this mother of 6 says she earns 100,000 shillings. This loan will help her to expand her business by buying more materials like containers to keep her flowers in.

loans.use: to purchase containers in which to keep her flowers

loans.name: Donadi

texts.en:
N. Donaid's main source of income for the past 3 years has been selling food such as maize grains, groundnuts and sorghum in Muhoro trading centre, Kyenjojo. With the earnings from his business, this hard-working and determined man has managed to sustain his family of 3 children. This 35-year-old, dynamic businessman has reached a point where his profits are now 900,000 Ugandan shillings a month. With steady progress in his small business, he reckons his future prospects are rising with every passing day.

With this loan, Donadi has the conviction that he will be able to buy more cash crops such as maize and beans so that he does not run short of stock. This will improve his sales revenue and will enable him to have a self-sustaining life as he looks to the future to educating his children. In that way, they will become important people who can support themselves in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more stock, like maize and beans, for resale

loans.name: Gulisa's Group

texts.en:
Gulisa K. is the leader of this group. She is 31 and divorced. She has two daughters and a son; all of them are at school.  Two years ago, with the initial investment of 5000 soms, she started to cultivate strawberries. By selling strawberries she makes 4000 soms per month. This profit has made it possible for her to save money and to purchase furniture. 

Gulisa applied for this loan because she needs money to hire labor to collect the harvest. In the future she wants to expand her business and to improve her living conditions.
 
Kenjekan J. is the treasurer of the group. She has two children; both of them are at school. Two years ago, with the initial investment of 9000 soms, Kenjekan and her husband rented a bakery. They started to provide bread to different shops and they make 13000 soms per month. With this loan she wants to purchase flour to make bread. In the future she wants to improve her living conditions and to purchase a fridge.

Talaibek T. is 46 and divorced. He has a daughter and a son; both of them are at school. He breeds cattle which he resells at a higher price after fattening. With this loan he wants to purchase tow bulls for breeding. In the future he wants to repair his house and then save money to purchase a vehicle.

Almanbet C., 33, is married. He has a newborn daughter. In order to make money he cultivates strawberries which he sells. His wife takes orders and provides sewing services. They make 10000 soms per month. With this loan he wants to hire labor to collect the harvest. In the future he plans to purchase a vehicle. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to hire labor for collecting the harvest

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: she wants to buy a desk, chair and a machine

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa A. J. is a married woman with four children aged between 3 and 14. Her business is located at a very busy market known as Likoni in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attractions including the Indian ocean white beaches. 

She sells water to the local people. She has been in business for one year and she says that this business is profitable. She says the major challenge is water supply. When there is shortage of supply to the hawkers, she cannot continue her business. However, she works very hard to keep her business going well. She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy a water storage tank to be able to reserve water and to meet customer demand. 

She hopes to be a big supplier of water to households in the area in the future. She also hopes to own her own house. She describes herself as kind and understanding.

loans.use: to buy a water tank

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase new inventory

loans.name: Saivali

texts.en:
D. Saivali was born in 1965 and is married with five children. As an aspiring and hard-working man, he has always dreamed of achieving success in whatever he does. For the past five years, Saivali has been growing melon, watermelon and onion in his land. At the same time, he raises cattle. Saivali wants his children to get a good education, allowing them to have a better chance to succeed in the future. This is what makes his sacrifice worthwhile. Currently Saivali requests $2,000 USD in order to buy seeds, mineral fertilizer and cattle. He plans to use the profits from his business to educate his children, improve the structure of his home, and improve the standard of living of his family.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more provision and drinks

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: expand and progress her business

loans.name: Ferdinard Ireri

texts.en:
Ferdinard is a 58-year-old man married to Lucy Mutitu. They have six children, two of whom are dependent on him. He runs a greengrocer shop. He has been in the business for a period of about sixth months now. He has been making a profit of approximately $63 a month.

He intends to use the loan to add more stock of fruits and vegetables. He was introduced to KADET LTD by his friends.  He hopes to have all his children through with their studies and to be stable in the future. He also wants to use the profit to renovate his house and open a permanent store for his goods.

loans.use: Buy more stock of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Yormahmad

texts.en:
D. Yormahmad is 53 years old. He is married and has three children. Yormahmad is a market vendor. He has been selling fruit for eleven years already. During these years Yormahmad has acquired the knowledge and skills required for the business. For instance, he knows how to store the fruits so as to keep their marketable conditions and not to lose their taste and useful properties. 

He sells fruit such as apples, peaches and pomegranates in the local central market. In the market he is known among people because of the attractive prices and his characteristic frendliness. All this allows Yormahmad’s business to generate a considerable stable income for his family. 

Due to the current season, Yormahmad’s goods are in high demand. For this reason he is planning to purchase more fruit for selling. He is requesting a loan of $1500 that will allow him to expand his business. Yormahmad thanks everyone for supporting him.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increasing of the range of fruits for selling

loans.name: Noziramo

texts.en:
K. Noziramo is 47 years old. She and her husband have four children. Noziramo is a kindergarten teacher; however, for several years she has been selling clothing for kids. She spends the income from the business on educating her children, as she and her husband are dreaming that their children will move on into higher education. 

Noziramo has been provided with loans by IMON in the past and has proven to be an accurate and reliable client. Today she is requesting 10,000 TJS for purchasing new goods to sell. Noziramo and her children sincerely thank you for your generous heart.

loans.use: To increase the range of goods for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy cloth and quilt making supplies

loans.name: Knight

texts.en:
Knight V. is a married woman with two children who are seven and two years old. She hopes to provide them with a quality education to the university level. 

Her business is located at a very busy market known as Likoni in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is part of the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its many tourist attraction sites, including the white beaches of the Indian Ocean. She owns a general store in which she sells such items as kerosene, detergents, sugar, flour and others. She has been in this business for three years now and she has two employees. 

She says that this business is profitable, but the major challenge she has is that some of her customers are not paying their debts as per agreement, making it hard for her to maximize profits. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. 

She is using her loan of 20,000 KES to buy more general items to expand her business and to meet the demands of her customers. She hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. She describes herself as obedient and tolerant.

loans.use: To buy kerosene, sugar, maize flour, etc. to sell

loans.name: Mahmadsaid

texts.en:
J. Mahmadsaid is a very hard-working and enterprising man who works at cultivating his farmland. It is to his crop that he owes his daily bread, so he tries to take care of it as best he can. 

Mahmadsaid is one of the most dedicated farmers, and every morning the town sees him walking to his work. He is one of the most respected people in the area and is known as an example for his children and the rest of the town. The courage and perseverance he puts into his job as a farmer is what stands out in this man, who is devoted to his family and his farmland. 

Nonetheless, he has difficulties and financial problems that are bringing him irregularities and losses. For this reason, Mahmadsaid is requesting your help with a loan of $1000 to increase his production with the purchase of additional seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Mahbuba

texts.en:
Mahbuba is a 29-year-old married mother of two children. Her husband is an entrepreneur and Mahbuba started her business seven years ago in order to support her family. 

All year she sells fruits that she buys from local farmers. Twice a week, Mahbuba travels over 20 km to sell her produce for attractive prices at the busy market. With the loan of 5,000 TJS from Kiva, she plans to increase the range of her selling goods and to buy more fruits for selling.

Mahbuba strives to give her children a better life than they have, including supporting them through a good education. Mahbuba is a well spoken, friendly businesswoman who is worthy of the support of Kiva partners.

loans.use: Increasing of the range of fruits for selling

loans.name: Nurullo

texts.ru: Калонов Нурулло проживает в городе Турсунзаде. Возраст, 49 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Нурулло имеет среднее образование. Занимается разведением скота. Он в основном откармливает и продает  крупно – рогатый скот. В этой области уже 25 лет. Кредит берет для закупа дойной коровы и корма (сено, комбикорм).
texts.en:
Nurullo K. lives in the city of Tursun-zoda. He is 49 years old, married, and has five children. His wife is a housewife. Nurullo has a high school education. He raises cattle. In general, he fattens and sells cattle. He has been doing this work for 25 years. He is taking out a loan to buy a milk cow and feed (hay, mixed fodder).

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying a milk cow

loans.name: Mahram

texts.en:
R. Mahram is 51 years old, married, and has four children. She started her own business ten years ago because her husband’s salary was not enough to cover their family expenses. She sells confectionery like candies, cookies and pastries in the local market. The income she generates allows Mahram to support her family. 

Mahram dreams of educating all of her children with a higher education. Today she is requesting 4,300 TJS. She is going to spend the loan for purchasing confectionery to enlarge the range of goods she sells. She is planning to spend the income for the well being of her family as well as for educating her children.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing confectionery for enlarging the range of goods

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret M. W. is twenty-six years old, is single, and does not have any children yet. Her business is well known as Rakendwa Hotel, a restaurant located at a busy market called Likoni in Mombasa, Kenya. Mombasa is in the coastal region of Kenya and is well known for its very many tourist attraction sites, not forgetting the Indian Ocean’s white beaches.

Margaret has been selling food to the local people and business people at Likoni for the last three years and has managed to employ two people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge she has is security.

Margaret is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy seats and tables to expand her business, therefore serving many people at one particular time. She hopes to expand and own a hotel, not just a restaurant. She describes herself as social and kind.

loans.use: To buy seats and tables for her restaurant

loans.name: Maisa

texts.en:
Maisa M. is a 24 years old woman from Jabalia refugee camp in Gaza Strip, Maisa is a wife and mother of one daughter and one son. Maisa and her husband Hussam A Dein work in the farm together taking care of hens and raising them.

Maisa and Hussam have started their project three months ago, and they still need a lot of work to have it as they want. Maisa came to FATEN and took a $1,500 loan to purchase more hens and feeds. Maisa and Hussam raise laying hens, they started also distributing to few shops and would like to expand their network.

Hussam A Dein pictures here in the farm as Maisa didn't want to show in the picture for sociA. reasons.

loans.use: buy hens feed

loans.name: Ikromidin

texts.ru: Калонов Икромидин житель города Турсунзаде. Возраст, 42 года. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Икромидин имеет средне - специальное образование. Работает по специальности. Кроме того занимается животноводством. Он разводит скот в дальнейшем для перепродажи. Этим видом деятельности занимается уже 20 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупно – рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Ikromidin K. is a resident of Tursun-zoda. He is 42 years old, married, and has four children. His wife is a housewife. Ikromidin has a vocational education. He works in his profession. Additionally, he works in animal husbandry. He raises cattle for resale. He has been doing this work for twenty years. He is taking out a loan to buy cattle.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Hanan

texts.en:
Hanan is a housewife and mother of two daughters and four sons, one of her sons works in a company in Ramallah while the others are still students. Hanan's husband is a school teacher.
Hanan's oldest son got married recently, and Hanan wanted to help her son pay off a part of the wedding expenses as he couldn't cover it all. So, she came to FATEN and received a $3,000 loan, which helped her son have his wedding on time.

Hanan who appears in the picture at FATEN's office is a very decent mother from Jineen

loans.use: Pay off wedding expenses

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old married woman and mother of one child. She has almost four years of experience selling accessories and jewelry to local customers.

She has decided to start her own business to help her husband with the household expenses. With her loan of $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l., she will be able to expand her inventory with a selection of new accessory collections. She has high hopes for the future of her business; she is looking to continue expansion of her business in the coming year.

Women continue to play an important role in Lebanese society, especially in the development of the family. Women like our borrower are able to serve as strong role models for their children while also helping to supplement their household incomes. In almost all parts of Lebanon, demand for beauty and fashion products continues to be high.

loans.use: To expand her inventory

loans.name: Peter Muriithi

texts.en:
Peter Murithi is a 31-year-old rice farmer. He is married to Eunice Murugi and has a son. Peter has been a rice farmer for a period of two years now with a profit of about Kshs 20,000 per month.

Peter learned about KADET through other clients. He intends to use the loan to buy fertilizers and spraying chemicals for his rice farm. He hopes to have a bright future as he is planing to develop his land and have a permanent house.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and spraying chemicals for his rice farm

loans.name: Shabana's Group

texts.en:
Shabana lives in Gujranwala which is a well-known industrial city in Pakistan. She is a 40-year-old lady who married A. H. nineteen years ago; she has been living in Gujranwala since her marriage. She is the mother of five daughters and two sons. Four out of seven are receiving an education. It is not possible for Shabana to send all of her children to school with her current financial situation.

Shabana’s eldest son drives a rickshaw. He left his education after completing his 8th standard and decided to work to contribute to the family financially. Shabana supports her family by doing sewing and embroidery work. She deals with good number of clients and receives regular orders.

Shabana has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s shoe-making business. With the loan, her husband will buy items such as leather, a shoe polisher and nails in large quantity to fulfill his larger orders on time. He receives orders from different factories and shoe shops.

Shabana is very confident that this investment will bring positive changes to her husband’s business and that her family will be able to improve their living standard. This is her 2nd loan.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy required items for his shoe-making business

loans.name: Molek

texts.en: Molek N. is 53 years old. She is widow and has three sons, two of whom help her in the household. Molek was the fourth child in a large, low-income family. Because she had to help her mother in the household from early childhood, Molek left secondary school after the 7th grade and started to work as a dairymaid. When Molek got married, she gave a birth to her beloved children. In 2003, her family met a hard blow – her husband died and Molek became the only bread-winner for the family. She decided to start her business in cattle breeding, since she had been engaged in cattle breeding for a long time and had a wide experience in this activity. She worked hard and managed to develop her farm: today she has three milk cows, one bull, one horse and twenty-two sheep. Her sons help her in pasturing and maintaining her livestock. In 2009, Molek obtained her first loan from Bai Tushum and Partners and repaid it without any delays. Now, she is applying for a loan of 60,000 KGS to buy two more milk cows in order to increase her milk sales. Molek is a very positive person so she believes that her strong efforts will help to improve her family’s standard of living. About Bai-Tushum and Partners: Bai-Tushum and Partners uses Kiva funding to target the especially vulnerable members of the population. It is one of the leading microfinance institutions in Kyrgyzstan. As a reliable financial partner, it contributes to the economic development of the Kyrgyz Republic through the delivery of microfinance services in rural and urban areas that lead to increased employment and meet the interests of its clients and investors.

loans.use: To purchase two more milk cows

loans.name: Justus

texts.en:
Justus is 48 years old and married to Esther Wanjiru who is also a business lady and earns a monthly income of about Kshs 8,000  to help cater for the family needs; they have four children.  Justus has been operating a motorcycle transport business for the past year with a monthly profit of approximately 19000 Kenya shillings. 

He was introduced to KADET LTD by a credit officer through marketing outreach. This is his first loan and he wants to use it to buy motorcycle spare parts for repair.  He intends use the profit generated to buy an extra motorcycle and pay for his children’s school fees. 

Justus' hopes and dreams are to buy a fleet of motorcycles and create jobs for other people. He also hopes to educate his children to tertiary level and support them until they have good incomes. He describes himself as an ambitious and hardworking businessman.

loans.use: Buy motorcycle spare parts

loans.name: Agrivina Wangari

texts.en:
Wangari is 24 years old and married to Paul Munithi who is a businessman. She is newly married but takes care of her orphaned niece. She is a tailor and she also sells new clothes. She has been in the business for a period of ten years now with a monthly profit of approximately Kshs 7,000. 

She intends to use the loan to buy more tailoring materials and boost her husband's business. She was introduced to KADET LTD by KADET staff. She hopes to introduce a uniforms section in the tailoring business.

loans.use: Buy more textiles for dressmaking

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: increase his merchandise selection and purchase prepaid telephone cards for resale

loans.name: Alexander Kinyua

texts.en:
Alexander Kinyua is  38 years old and married to Jedidah Wachuka who is a housewife. He buys watermelons from farmers and distributes to Nanyuki town and Nairobi. He has been in the business for a period of about five years now.  Alex makes a profit of about Kshs. 10,000 per month.

He intends to use the loan to add more stock of watermelons to wholesale. He was introduced to KADET LTD by KADET LTD staff. He hopes to develop his land in Nyeri in order to uplift the standard of living of his family.

loans.use: To increase his stock by buying watermelons

loans.name: Deo

texts.en:
K. Deo is a warmly polite 40-year-old married father of five kids who all attend school in Nagatule-Kampala. Selling herbal natural medicines is the business of this courteous and cordial gentleman who had a preference for them on the basis of the high demand for them, especially in most parts of Kampala where people are destitute and cannot afford hospital medication. 

Thirteen years is the time he has been plying this business and it is a business he began with savings from his cooking oil sales savings.  Per week, Deo says he makes profits totaling up to 250,000 shillings. With this loan he wants to improve his business. The first thing he intends to do is get a permanent rental place in town where he will be able to stock his products for sale on a larger scale.

loans.use: Rental fees for a new outlet in town

loans.name: White Group

texts.en:
Matthew A. is in his mid-forties and is married with two children, aged 12 and 9. Matthew operates a small food shop that he has been running for 10 years. The shop is open daily between 12 am and 11pm and he is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be Matthew’s 3rd 'Motisha' loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. A 'Mothisha' loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term would have ended. He used his previous two loans on increasing shop inventory, and both have been successfully repaid. He aims to use his third loan on buying more land. Matthew’s dream is to one day build a house for himself on this new land.

 

Matthew will share this loan with his loan group, White, which has 6 members. The members of the group will hold each other responsible for repaying the loans.

 

In the picture, Matthew is seen in the first row, on the left, wearing a black suit.

loans.use: To buy land to one day build a house

loans.name: Baha

texts.en:
Baha is a young man from Jineen who works in Israel. Baha installs kitchen marble and its accessories in houses. Baha has his own workshop where he manages his work which he started three years ago.

Baha needed a $2,000 loan which he received from FATEN to increase his capital and purchase more material to do his job.

Baha wants to expand his workshop and attract more customers, as his project is successful and bringing back good returns.

Baha appears in the picture here in FATEN's office.

loans.use: Purchase needed material

loans.name: Marion

texts.en: Marion is 36 years old, married and a mother of two.  For two years, she has been practicing dairy farming.  She is also employed and she earns a salary every month. Therefore, she boosts her income with the dairy business.  Since she joined Faulu Kenya, her income has increased.  Besides, she is able to feed her animals well and her living standards have improved.  She has requested 40,000 Kes. to buy another cow. She describes herself as ambitious, hardworking and patient.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Dickson

texts.en:
Dickson is 26 years old, married with one child.  He has been operating Imani Dispensing chemist for four years.  His wife assists him in running the business.  He is a hardworking and focused man who hopes to open a wholesale outlet for his business.  

Dickson says that his business has improved since he joined Faulu Kenya and he is able to provide for his family.  He has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to purchase a water dispenser.

loans.use: To purchase a water dispenser

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is a member of 'Huruma B' group in Faulu Kenya.  He is married to a business-lady who sells tomatoes wholesale while he sells bananas.  He was previously selling sugarcane to earn a living.  He hopes to see his children acquire the best education.  He has requested his first loan of 15,000 KES from Faulu Kenya.  With the loan, he will buy more bananas for resale.

loans.use: To buy more bananas for resale

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Great Hope Development Group-Lugazi

texts.en:
34-year-old A. Harriet who belongs to 'Great Hope' development group, Mukono, is uncompromisingly relentless as regards running her 5-year-old cosmetics  sales business in a way that she says will make her make more profit and above all establish a good reputation for her business. 

With this sense of purpose she has made great strides in terms of attracting customers who range from low, middle to high income earners within her Kito locality, Mukono. This has translated into increased sales and hence more profits. 

 Being a family-oriented woman, these circumstances have been momentous for her as she has, based on her business, sought the betterment of her family.  Harriet pays tribute to her husband who she says pep-talked her into setting forth in this business. In a month, this mother of one makes 70,000 shillings. With this loan she says she is going to buy more boxes of cosmetics for resale and also purchase machines to use in her beauty salon.

loans.use: purchase more boxes of cosmetics for resale and machines to use in her beauty salon

loans.name: Nyabubare Intergrated Farmers Group

texts.en:
Hardworking K. Magidu has been running his business for over five years, selling produce including maize, sorghum, millet, beans and groundnuts as an additional source of income alongside pineapple sales. His business prospers because maize flour used in prepared food is in high favor with many Ugandans.

In Nyabubare, Bushenyi, this 52-year-old married father of eight is referred to as the early riser with the lark. He is a stickler for hard work and as such his children are all basking in the glow of his enterprising nature as he has been able to pay up their school dues. This business brings him monthly profits of 120,000 Ugandan shillings, and he is looking at business expansion in the future. With this loan he will purchase more stock to help meet the increasing demand from his customers and thereby earn more revenue.

loans.use: To purchase  more stock

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: purchase more cheese-making machines and more ghee for  resale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 28-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She lives with her mother and two siblings.  She has been working selling souvenirs and gifts for the past 8 years. And from September 2009, she is the proud owner of a souvenir shop in her town. She is very happy with her new business and because she is finally able to help her mother with the household expenses. 

To reinforce her business level, she is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to buy different merchandise: souvenirs, gadgets and gifts. In the future, she is planning to further expand her shop and start to sell handicrafts and handmade items because her area is known as a touristic site and this type of shop is very attractive to the tourists.

loans.use: to buy different merchandise: souvenirs, gadgets and gifts

loans.name: Escarlete

texts.es: Escarlete vive en casa de sus padres en la zona de sopocachi de la ciudad de La Paz, tiene 28 años de edad y es egresada de la carrera de arquitectura,actualmente está soltera y no tiene hijos. Escarlete trabaja en la Alcaldía Municipal de La Paz en Villa San Antonio en la sección barrios de verdad donde percibe un sueldo con el cual se mantiene. El crédito es para comprar una computadora y preparar su tesis para poder titularse y de esta manera poder ascender a un cargo mejor en la institución donde trabaja.
texts.en:
Escarlete lives in her parents’ house in the Sopocachi neighbourhood of La Paz. She is 28 years old and graduated in architecture from university. At the moment she is single and has no children. Escarlete works for the Municipality of La Paz in Villa San Antonio in the “Barrios de Verdad” program. She supports herself on the salary she receives. The loan would be used to buy a computer on which to prepare her thesis so she can obtain her professional qualification. This will enable her to take on more responsibilities in the institution where she works.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy a computer

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn V. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Kalubihan, Brgy. Libertad, Escalante City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a sari-sari (general) store  business.  Her husband Edgardo V., who is 43 years old, works as a truck driver to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have six children who range from an infant up to  20 years old. 

Jocelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1995 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 9 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jocelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 2,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 10th loan, she is borrowing PHP 17,000 which she intends to use as additional capital for her general store so that she can continue to save up for her children's education.  Jocelyn V. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. In the photo you will see Jocelyn with her baby. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital for general store

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Luzminda

texts.en:
Luzminda A. is a married woman who lives in Prk. 2, Brgy. Asia, Hinobaan, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures:   Fishing, Fruit Retailing, and Pig Fattening businesses. Her husband Rodrigo, who is 41 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have seven children who are 6 to  16 years old. 

Luzminda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Luzminda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 18,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,500, which she intends to use to buy more fishing gear and additional hogs to raise so that she can continue to save up for the education of her children and support the family. Luzminda A. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Buy more fishing gear

loans.name: Tumwesigye Women's Group-Mukono

texts.en:
39-year-old M. Firida belongs to Tumwesigye women’s group, Mukono. For the last 20 years she and her family have been counting on profits from fish sales in Mpunge for their subsistence.  Firida is happily married and she is happy to credit her husband with the inspiration to set forth in this business.

 Prior to taking root in this business she was involved in tailoring.  Her hard work and determination has gotten her this far, she says. All her five children are in school as a result of her hard work which sees her make Shillings 400,000 a  week. She also has a sideline dairy business that she says helps her supplement her profits. With this loan she wants to buy more fishing nets and also a dairy cow. This, she says, will go a long way toward helping her financially strengthen her business.

loans.use: The purchase of  more fishing nets and also a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 52-year-old married woman from Lebanon. From the past fifteen years, she has been selling a wide range of goods from her home to customers from her community. She is well known in her town for the delicious home-made products she produces.

She believes that her business would be better if she were to sell her goods in a different part of Lebanon. That’s why, she is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase milk in order to produce Lebanese food products and deliver her products to other areas.  In the future, she would like to rent a space to sell her merchandise from, as well as selling her popular home-made food products. For the time being, she will continue to sell goods from her home.

loans.use: to purchase milk

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth D. is a 40-year-old married woman who supports her family by running a Sari- Sari (general) Store, Food Vending and beauty products sales.  She lives in Locatha, Brgy. Looc, Lapu-Lapu City, Cebu. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since March 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store, food vending and beauty products businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 30,000. Lilibeth is now borrowing PHP 20,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell.  This will be her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom. Lilibeth aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way.  

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Santos Roberto

texts.es:
Don Santos tiene 47 años de edad, está casado y vive junto a su esposa y dos hijos el mayor de 4 años, ellos administran un pequeño negocio donde ofrecen comida y venden productos de la canasta básica, el negocio fue iniciativa propia y juntos lo tienen desde hace 12 años trabajando desde las ocho de la mañana hasta las diez de la noche.
Él solicita un préstamo para invertirlo en mercadería y aumentar su negocio, ayudando a que su inventario este fuerte y puedan cubrir con las demandas de los clientes; ellos desean comprar gaseosas, jugos, queso, jamón, y otros que le son necesario para la preparación de la comida que ofrecen cada día a los clientes.
El sueño de don Santos es crecer con su negocio, aumentar sus ingresos para darle una mejor vida a su familia y poder educar a sus hijos.
texts.en:
47-year old Don Santos is married and lives with his wife and two children, the elder of whom is four years old. He and his wife run a small business where they sell food and other basic supplies. They started the business on their own initiative and have had it for twelve years, working from 8 am to 10 pm. Santos is seeking a loan to buy merchandise and stock his business with more products. This way he will be able to satisfy his customers’ requests. He wishes to buy such items as soft drinks, juices, cheese, ham, and whatever else he needs for the food he offers each day to his customers. Santos’s dream is to expand the business and increase his income so that he can provide a better life for his family and education for his children.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise for his store

loans.name: Ejoheza Group

texts.en: “Ejoheza” (meaning a bright future in the Kinyarwanda language) is a group of 30 clients. They sell different things. Some sell second-hand clothes, food crops, or fruit and others have bars. Olive (raising a hand in the photo) is the group president. She has a shop in which she sells items such as salt, soap, sugar, etc. Olive is 45 years old; she has three children who are between the ages of 17-21 years old.One of her children is in school while the other two stopped their studies after their six primary grades because she couldn’t afford their school fees. Olive sells bicycle spare parts and she is requesting a loan to buy more spare parts and fill her store in order to make more profits.  With the profits she hopes to open up a wholesale shop. She has been in this business for three years and she finds it interesting because it enables her to cover most of her home expenses. Most of the other group members wish to reinvest in their businesses.

loans.use: spare bicycle parts

loans.name: Billy

texts.en:
Billy S. is a 45-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating three business ventures:   General Store, Pig Fattening and charcoal sales. She lives in Proper, Brgy. Maricalum, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. 

By working hard in her General Store, Pig Fattening and charcoal businesses. She is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 10,000 PHP. Billy is now borrowing  28,000 PHP so that she  can  fund operations of her three businesses and buy more stock to sell.   This will be her 25th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 24,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Billy aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: additional working capital

loans.name: Gertrudes

texts.en:
Gertrudes O. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Kaungkod, Madredijos, Cebu City. She earns her living by operating two business ventures:  general store and pig fattening businesses. Her husband Juan O., who is 48 years old, works as a carpenter to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have five children who are 15 to 22 years old. 

Gertrudes joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 12 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Gertrudes has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 19,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 4000 thus, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 13 loan, she is borrowing PHP 29,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell so that she can continue to save up for her family's future security and improve their living conditions. She also wants to save enough so that she can have additional capital to invest back to her businesses. Gertrudes O. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

 In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn T. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. 4, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: Videoke rental, coconut shell sales and fish vending. Her husband Jenises, who is 31 years old, works as a Security Guard to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 3 children who are 8 to 10 years old.

Jenelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Jenelyn has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of 8000 PHP helped her earn a monthly profit of 5000 PHP, uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 12th loan cycle, she is borrowing 15000 PHP, with which she intends to purchase one more videoke machine. This will increase her income and she will continue to save up for the future improvement of their house and the education of their children. Jenelyn T. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase New Equipment

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna S. is a 45 year old married woman who supports her family by operating 2 business ventures; a general store and a pig fattening business. She lives in Brgy. Pasil, Santander, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005, and has improved her living conditions with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and pig fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 10,000.

Lorna is now borrowing PHP 16000 so she can purchase additional stock for sale. This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 13000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Lorna aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase additional stock for sale

loans.name: Susana Salome

texts.es:
Susana tiene 21 años D. edad, resiD. en el Departamento D. Usulután donD. vive junto a su esposo y su pequeño hijo D. dos años D. edad, ella se dedica a la elaboración D. artesanías desD. hace 3 años y comenzó este negocio por iniciativa propia siempre viendo la forma D. ayudar con los gastos del hogar, ella trabaja desD. las ocho D. la mañana hasta las cinco D. la tarD. fabricando collares, pulseras entre otros productos que le son demandados.
Susana solicita un préstamo para la inversión D. su negocio, ya que necesita comprar materiales para elaborar artesanía, este préstamo ayudara a que su inventario D. materiales sea abundante y pueda contar con los recursos necesarios para cubrir con la demanda, también crecerá su negocio fortaleciendo sus ganancias y aumentaran sus clientes.
El sueño D. ella es tener un negocio granD., en mejores condiciones, ayudar a sus hijo para su desarrollo y cambiar la calidad D. vida D. su familia.
texts.en:
Susana is 21 years old, she lives in the Usulután department with her husband and her little son aged 2. She has been engaging in making handicrafts for 3 years: she started this activity of her own volition in a constant attempt to find a way to help facing her family’s expenses. She works form 8 am to 5 pm making necklaces, bracelets and many other products, according to the requests she receives. Susana is asking for a loan to invest in her activity, as she needs to buy materials to create handicrafts. She will use to this loans to better supply her stock and so be able to count on the necessary resources to face her requests; this will also make her business grow by consolidating her income and increasing the number of her customers. Her main goals are to own a big shop with better conditions, to be able to proviD. for her son through his growing up years and to change her family’s quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Emanuela Villa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materilas to produce handicrafts.

loans.name: Amie

texts.en:
Amie V. is a 38-year old married woman who supports her family by operating as a Fish Dealer and Retailer. She lives in Brgy. 2, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her Fish Dealer and Retailer business, she is gradually making her family economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 8000 PHP.

Amie is borrowing 10000 PHP so she can purchase more bulk fish stock for sale. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 25000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Amie aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: purchase bulk fish stocks for sale

loans.name: Ma. Linda

texts.en: Ma. Linda S. is a married woman who lives in Upper Liloan, Santander, Cebu. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: a sari-sari store, a carenderia (mini restaurant) and pig fattening. Her husband, Pedro S., who is 54 years old, helps Linda with the businesses. They have five children who are from 20 to 30 years old with four of them having their own families and only one currently going to school. Ma. Linda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2007 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past five loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 6th loan, Ma. Linda is borrowing PHP 15,000, which she intends to use as additional working capital so that she can continue to save more so that she can send her children to school, especially to college. Ma. Linda is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Shafqat's Group

texts.en:
Shafqat is 50 years old and is a seamstress. She has to work at this older age in order to put three meals a day on the table for her family. She is old but she is not disheartened by her financial situation. She lives in a big industrial city in Pakistan called Gujranwala. Her husband operates a donkey cart. He transports goods to earn an income for his family.

Shafqat has a great supporting nature. She has a daughter who married A. Aziz a few years ago. A. Aziz drives a rickshaw which is in need of repair and maintenance because, due to its roughness and poor condition, he can’t seat his passengers and continue his work. Therefore, Shafqat has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah to help A. Aziz with his business. With the loan, he will repair his rickshaw to do his job more efficiently.

Shafqat is a regular Asasah loan user and this is her 2nd loan.

loans.use: To pay for the repair and maintenance of her son-in-law's rickshaw

loans.name: Ma. Luz

texts.en:
Ma. Luz M. is a 43-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: a general store and a hog-raising business. She lives in Banquerohan, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental.

Ma. Luz has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2004 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and hog-raising businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 30,000.

Ma. Luz is now borrowing PHP 15,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 10th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.

Ma. Luz aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way.


About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Consorcia

texts.en: Consorcia N. is a widow who lives in Barangay Poblacion, Santander, Cebu. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a sari-sari store and a pig-fattening business. She has three children who are from 24 to 28 years old. Consorcia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past twelve loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 28,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8,000, thus uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 13th loan, Consorcia is borrowing PHP 28,000 which she intends to use to buy additional groceries to sell in her general store. This will enable her to continue to save for her future security and to support the daily expenses of her family. Consorcia is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more stock to sell in her general store

loans.name: Rosa Amelia

texts.es:
Doña Rosa tiene 58 años de edad vive junto a su esposo en el Departamento de San Miguel, ella se dedica a la venta de Ropa comercializándola  en el mercado municipal del municipio de Jucuapa desde hace 21 años con un horario de ocho de la mañana a cuatro de la tarde; Ella quiere crecer con su negocio y por el momento no cuenta con los fondos necesarios para realizar la inversión por lo que doña Rosa está solicitando un préstamo para comprar mas mercadería como blusas, faldas, camisas y ropa interior, ya que son prendas demandadas por sus clientes.
Este préstamo ayudará que ella crezca con el negocio, aumenten sus ventas y ofrezca mejores y más prendas de vestir a sus clientes.
El sueño de doña Rosa es aumentar su negocio, generar los ingresos necesarios para el sustento diario de su familia.
texts.en:
Rosa is 58 years old and she lives with her husband in the San Miguel department. For 21 years she has been selling clothes in the municipal market of the town of Jucuapa: she works form 8 am to 4 pm.
