About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rene

texts.en: Rene L. is from the village of Babahagon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 48 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Rene owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-five years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month. In 2010, Rene joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta O. is from the village of Balila, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 43 years old. Julieta is married and has nine school-aged children. Julieta owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Julieta joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Julieta from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Pat Chek Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of sixteen people who live in Chroung Sdau village in Takeo province. They have chosen Mrs. Pat C., born in 1972, to become a village bank president. Each group member will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. Mrs. Pat C. and her husband are farmers who own a small piece of land to cultivate rice to sell in order to support their famiL.'s costs of living. They also own a wedding hall for rent to people. Her problem is that her field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, Mrs. Pat C. is seeking for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan, she will hire a plow machine to plow her rice field. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, another one is helping the father do business, one is a student and the youngest one is onL. five years old.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria R. is from the village of Balila, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 52 years old. Gloria is married and has seven adult children. Gloria owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Gloria joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gloria from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia P. is from the village of Balila, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old. Emelia is married and has three adult children. Emelia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Emelia has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Emelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Emelia is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Emelia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira D. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 40 years old. Elvira is widowed and has four school-aged children. Elvira owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Elvira has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Elvira joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Elvira is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elvira from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About HSPFI:

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria R. is from the village of Arabiat Echague. She is 41 years old. Gloria is married and has five school-aged children. Gloria owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gloria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it. 

About ASKI:

loans.name: Santos Carminda

texts.es: La sra. Santos Carminda R. tiene 35 años de edad, es casada y tiene tres hijos de 10,12 y14 años, y junto a su familia reside en el Barrio Guanacaste en San Esteban, Olancho. Es una persona muy trabajadora, su primer negocio lo tuvo hace seis años y fue un comedor, pero desde hace dos años se dedica a la venta de abarrotería. Tiene una pequeña pulpería que funciona en su domicilio, con un horario de atención de 6:00 am 9:00 pm. Su principal ventaja es que no hay otra pulpería en el barrio y eso le permite que todos sus vecinos hagan sus compras en su pulpería. El préstamo lo necesita para comprar abarrotería para surtir su negocio de más y variados productos. Su meta es tener un mercadito y que este le permita obtener mayores ganancias para seguir apoyando a sus hijos con el estudio porque ella desea que sean profesionales universitarios y también que su calidad de vida mejore.
texts.en:
Señora Santos Carminda R. is 35 years old, married and has three children ages 10, 12 and 14. She lives with her family in the Guanacaste neighborhood in San Esteban, Olancho. She is a very hard-working person. Six years ago she started her first business running a small restaurant, but for the past two years she has been selling groceries. She has a small store that she runs out of her house. Business hours are from 6:00 am until 9:00 pm. The main advantage of this business is that there are no other grocery stores in her neighborhood so all her neighbors shop at her store. She is requesting a loan to buy more groceries in order to increase and diversify her stock. Her goal is to have a small market that will bring in a better income so that she can continue supporting her children's studies. She would like to see them go to college and to improve their quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, corn, beans, sugar, coffee, bread, butter, churros, etc.

She works in the garment factory, typically making $2 US each day; her husband works in construction. Her husband typically makes about $2.50 each day. However, this couple need to take care their old father. Sok S. would like a loan of $1000 to make two investments. First, create a new business selling fruits and second, is used to build a house.

texts.en: Nhil S., 44, is married with five children living at home in the Kampong Chhnang province. She raises pigs and cows, typically making $1 US each day. Her husband works in construction, typically making about $3 each day. Nhil S. would like a loan of $800 to purchase more cows for resale.

loans.use: To purchase cows for resale

loans.name: Adelfa

texts.en:
Adelfa B. is single and lives the town of Prk. Malipayon, Brgy. Binicuil, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating a general store.  

Adelfa joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 because she wanted a better life for her family. With the help of sixteen loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Adelfa has been achieving her goal of lifting her family out of poverty, and doing it by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 21,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 25,000, which meant major improvements in her family's lifestyle.  

Adelfa has applied for her 17th loan, for PHP 22,500, which she intends to use to buy more items to sell to her customers. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To buy more items to sell to her customers

texts.en:
Janet E. has been able to sustain her butcher shop thanks to a previous loan from KIVA lenders. She repaid that loan and used her profits to supplement her husband’s irregular income and pay for the education of her children.

Janet is determined to improve bother her business and the life of her family. Knowing that she can access financial support through loans has given her courage and faith that someday all four of her children, whose ages range from seven to 18, will graduate from college and be ready to face life on their own. She is very passionate about giving all of her children a brighter future.

To make that possible, she is applying for a new loan to expand her business and pay for the quarterly license she needs to run her stall.

loans.name: Temotia

texts.en:
Temotia V., a married woman who lives in Brgy. Talisay, Santander, Cebu, earns her living through her food vending and pig fattening businesses. Her husband, Domingo V., 44, works as a farmer to earn his living. They have seven children ranging in age from 8 to 37, two of whom have their own families, while two others are employed and another is a student.

Temotia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired to something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Temotia has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 10000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. For her fifth loan, she is borrowing PHP 10000 to purchase business raw materials so that she can continue to save up for the future and send her children to school. Temotia V. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.name: Oyuntuya

texts.en:
Oyuntuya T. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and young son in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a "ger," a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her son, 4, attends a local kindergarten, while her husband is currently unemployed. 

Oyuntuya sells a variety of consumer goods out of a shipping container in her town. She started her business in 2006 by selling a variety of goods in an outdoor stall at the local market and has built a stable operation. Her earnings have enabled her to purchase a shipping container that she uses as a shop.

In the future, she hopes to expand her business and to operate a transportation business for her husband. Oyuntuya is a very open-minded and hardworking person and is requesting a 1,200,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase more inventory for increasing her working capital.

Depending on her sales, she travels once or twice a month to Ulaanbaatar to purchase products to sell.

loans.name: Ariun-Enh

texts.en:
Ariun-Enh M. is 33 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. They live together in a "ger," a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His oldest son attends a local secondary school while his youngest daughter is in kindergarten. His wife works as a seamstress in her home to supplement her family's income. 

Ariun-Enh operates a gold and silver crafts business in his town. He has much skill as a craftsman and designs and produces a variety of jewelry and accessories. He had been working for the Mungun Goyol company in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city, for several years as a craftsman. He started his own business in a rented stall at local market in 2008 after moving from Ulaanbaatar. Since then, he has moved to his home, where he makes his products by customer order. He usually makes silver cups, religious items, belts and saddles. All his products are known as high-quality with long durability and therefore, attract many customers. He is a very accurate and hardworking man. 

He is requesting a 2,000,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase more gold and silver for his jewelry-making business.

loans.use: To buy pig food

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch S., 45, is married, has three children and lives in Kampong Chnang province. She makes a living selling desserts, usually taking in about $3 a day. Her husband, who we see pictured here, works as a journalist and makes about $1.50 each day. Touch S. is applying for a loan for $700 to buy a motorbike which two of her children need to commute to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Balbina

texts.en:
Balbina G. lives in the village of Namabbalan Norte, Tuguegarao City. She is 44 years old, married and has three school-aged children. For the last two years, she has made a living by selling vegetables to people who live in her community. She earns about 2,000 PHP a month from her work.

Balbina joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is applying for a loan, her first, for 4,000 PHP, to buy additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated by her business to support her family. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell to her customers

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en:
Lawrence B. lives the village of Salamague Lamut, Ifugao. He is 29 years old, married and has two school-aged children. For the last two years, he has made a living by raising livestock. He earns about 5,000 PHP a month from his work.

Earlier this year, Lawrence joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his life and ability to engage in business. He is applying for his first loan, for 10,000 PHP, to expand his business. He plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to improve his family's living standards. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand a small livestock business

loans.name: 060209-Tien Phong-Hoang Chau Group

texts.en:
Lien T. T. (55) is a 38 year-old woman living in the town of Hoang Hoa. She is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 060209-Tien Phong-Hoang Chau (060209-Tien Phong-Hoang Chau).

Lien is widowed and has one adult child. To making a living, Lien operates a family member's business venture selling flowers. She has been engaged in this business for over seven years and earns approximately 1000000 VND a month.

In 2009, Lien joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3079800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women used to invest in expanding the business and is now requesting a new loan of 5000000 VND to invest in expanding the business. The loan will be the second taken out by Lien from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. 

About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  Ly L. T. (49) is a 26 year-old woman who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

2.  Thao L. T. (54) is a 37 year-old woman who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

3.  Oi L. T. (7) is a 58 year-old woman who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

4.  Xuan D. T. (56) is a 27 year-old woman who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Lien T. T. (55) là 38 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang Hoa.  Lien là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 5 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 060209-Tien Phong-Hoang Chau (060209-Tien Phong-Hoang Chau).

Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán hoa trong cộng đồng địa phương.  Lien thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 7 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Lien kiếm được khoảng 1,000,000 VND.  Vào 2009, Lien đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Lien đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND.

Khoản vay sẽ là 2nd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:

1.  Ly L. T. (49) là 26 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

2.  Thao L. T. (54) là 37 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

3.  Oi L. T. (7) là 58 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

4.  Xuan D. T. (56) là 27 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.

Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  D. việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Mrs. Chen Chantha Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Eleven people from Kdei Ta Hok village, Takeo province, make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Chen C. is 40 years old. She's become the village bank president selected by the other members, each of whom will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

She and her husband, Mr. Sao Phoung, are farmers who own a 1.3-hectare plot of land in which to cultivate rice to sell to support their family. She is also selling mosquito nets and blankets door-to-door, while her husband is raising ducks and chickens at home. 

Today, she wants to expand her husband’s poultry-raising business, but she does not have enough money. So to improve this goal, Mrs. Chen C. is requesting for a loan from AMK to buy chicken and duck food. She has two children who are in school.

loans.use: To buy chicken and duck food

loans.name: Maxima Leticia

texts.es: Máxima Leticia Pavón tiene 46 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene cinco hijos y varios nietos, y reside en Barrio Las Acacias en Juticalpa, Olancho. Máxima posee un puesto de frutas el cual tiene una excelente ubicación ya que está a un costado de la carretera que conduce hacia la Ciudad de Tegucigalpa y esta es muy transitada. En este puesto comercializa todo tipo de frutas, sobre todo aquellas que están de temporada. Inició su negocio hace 14 años con una chiclera y vendía churros, galletas, dulces, etc. pero luego de un tiempo se dio cuenta de que ese tipo de productos no eran atractivos para los transeúntes que pasaban por su puesto así que decidió vender frutas. Con el préstamo comprará una mayor cantidad de frutas como sandias, naranjas y bananos, y así podrá obtener más ganancias que le permitirán llevar el sustento a su familia y cubrir con los gastos escolares de su hijo menor. Una de las dificultades que enfrenta es que uno de sus nietos no camina ni habla y la mayor parte del tiempo tiene que estar hospitalizado y eso le ocasiona grandes gastos. Sus sueños son que la salud de su nieto mejore, tener un establecimiento propio que sea grande y bonito, y tener su propia casa ya que donde reside es alquilado y el pago de la renta mensual es muy caro. Desde hace seis años es clienta de FAMA y con los préstamos obtenidos ha podido superarse y tener una mejor vida económica.
texts.en:
Máxima Leticia Pavón is 46 years old and a single mother. She has five children and various nieces and nephews. She lives in the Las Acacias neighborhood in Juticalpa, Olancho. Máxima has a fruit stand that is located in very busy spot along the side of the road that leads to the city of Tegucigalpa. She sells all types of fruits, primarily those that are in season. She started her business 14 years ago selling candy, churros, cookies, etc., but realized that these types of products were not attractive to the people that passed by her stand. This is what prompted her to start selling fruit. With this loan she will buy a larger quantity of fruit such as watermelons, oranges and bananas. This will allow her to earn more and to continue supporting her family and cover her youngest child's educational expenses. One of the difficulties that she faces is that one of her nephews can't walk or talk and most of the time he is hospitalized. This is very expensive. Her dreams are that her nephew's health improves, to own a large and beautiful store and to own her own house as she is renting and her monthly payment is very expensive. She has been a FAMA client for six years. The loans have enabled her to better herself and to improve her economic situation.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase watermelons, oranges, bananas and other seasonal fruits

loans.name: Kalsoom's Group

texts.en: Kalsoom is from Vehari, a small city of Punjab, Pakistan known for agricultural. A very caring lady, Kalsoom stays at home and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife and mother very well. She is fond of cooking and prepares different types of healthy food for her family to make them healthy. Her husband, A. M., runs a grocery shop in the nearby market. His shop is always filled with kids and elders. Kids buys sweets and drinks and elders buy household items. He has been in this business for the past four years and has made good customers and a good reputation.  Kalsoom has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business to buy more grocery items for his grocery shop. She is hopeful that this investment will bring positive change to her husband’s business and that his income will improve which will help the family's financial condition.

loans.use: To buy groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to expand his business

loans.name: Tasleem's Group

texts.en: Tasleem (with raised hand) lives in Vehari, a small city of Pakistan known for agriculture. Her husband, K. H., sells agriculture supplies including seeds and fertilizer in his shop in the market. Since Vehari is a city where most of the people are involved in agriculture, his business is doing well. Tasleem helps support her family by making and selling cushion covers. She makes beautiful designs using hand embroidery which are much admired. Tasleem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With it he will buy seeds and fertilizers in large quantity for his shop. Tasleem says that her husband is experienced in his field and can make good use of the money to improve his business. She is hopeful that the investment will be productive for her family.

loans.use: To buy seeds & fertilizer to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Luy Sinorn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. L. S. was born in 1973. She was selected as the village bank president by the fourteen-member group located in Sramaoch Hae village in Takeo province. Members will use their portion of the loan for various goals to improve their standard of living.

Mrs. L. S. is a farmer who owns a 0.5 hectare plot of land to cultivate rice; she sells part of the rice yield to support her family, while her husband, Mr. Bol Ban, is a seamstress in a garment factory. Currently, she has a problem because her husband’s workplace is far away from their home. To improve this situation, she seeks a loan to buy a motorcycle for transport. Mrs. L. S. and her husband support four children, two of whom are students in school, while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia M. has enjoyed spending the profits from her farming business because it has enabled her to sustain the needs of her family and improve their lives. That encourages her to work harder and plan further for her business and family. Lilia wants to take the opportunity to grow her business by requesting another loan of 27,000 PHP from Kiva lenders for additional business capital to grow more rice to sell.

Her long-term goal is to have a successful farming business to support her family financially. With the support of Kiva lenders, she is determined to achieve business success with her new entrepreneurial endeavor. Lilia’s wish to offer her children the hope for a better life fuels her pledge to her project.

loans.use: to support and maintain her farming business.

loans.name: Santos Neptali

texts.es: Santos Neptali D. F., tiene 48 años de edad, reside en el Barrio La Pradera, en la Comunidad de San Esteban, Olancho. Vive junto a su esposa la cual se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar y también le ayuda a atender el negocio, y su hijo de 12 años que se dedica a estudiar. Santos posee una pequeña venta de abarrotería. Inició su negocio hace cinco años debido a la falta de oportunidad de tener un empleo. Santos trabaja junto a su esposa con el deseo de poder brindarle a su hijo una vida mejor, en la cual cuente con todo lo básico y necesario para una vida digna. Él solicita este préstamo para poder comprar una mayor cantidad de productos para la canasta básica y así tener bien surtida su pulpería. Santos desea que sus ventas aumenten para establecer otra pulpería a parte de la que ya tiene y así poder seguir invirtiendo en la educación de su hijo hasta que este obtenga su título universitario, porque está convencido de que si su hijo estudia tendrá mejores oportunidades de vida.
texts.en:
Santos Neptali D. F. is 48 years old and lives in the La Pradera neighborhood in the community of San Esteban, Olancho. He lives with his wife, who does the household chores and also helps him attend to the business, as well as his 12-year-old son who is a student.

Santos has a small grocery store. He started his business five years ago because of the lack of opportunity for employment. Santos works with his wife, both of whom want to be able to provide a better life for their son in which he has all of the basics and necessities for a decent life.

He is requesting this loan to be able to purchase a larger quantity of basic food items and have his store better stocked. Santos wants to increase his sales to establish a separate store so that he can continue investing in his son’s education until he receives his university degree because he is convinced that if his son studies, he will have better life opportunities.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase basic grains, pastas, churros, bread, flour, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase goods for reselling

loans.name: Nazar Mai Muhammad Shafee's Group

texts.en:
N. Mai lives in Vehari, which is located in Punjab, Pakistan. She owns a house of two rooms there and has been living in it with her family for over 10 years. 

She is a seamstress by profession. She supports her family by sewing clothes for her neighboring clients. She is a very active businesswoman and keeps herself up to date about new and coming fashions. The advantage of keeping up to date herself about new fashions is she easily understands her customers' demand for dressing and designs. Her business is going well and making her a good income every month. 

Her husband's name is M. S.. He operates a grocery shop in a nearby market, where he sells the usual grocery items to his clients. As the days are passing, he is facing tough competition with other shopkeepers because of their variety of products.  

Therefore, N. has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy grocery items such as lentils, cooking oil, spices and rice for his grocery shop and increase his sales.
   
N. is hopeful that her husband will be able to re-establish his business on a large scale and fulfill the needs of his customers.

loans.use: To buy groceries for a grocery shop

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy materials for her business

loans.name: Mrs. Yoss Chanthy Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Yoss C. is applying for a village bank loan for nine people who live in Sramaoch Hae village in Takeo province. Mrs. C. was selected as the village bank loan president by the other bank members, each of whom will use his or her portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. C. was born in 1974 and has three children, all of whom are attending school. She and her husband, Mr. Nunh Chamroeun, are farmers who own a 1-hectare plot of land on which they cultivate rice to sell and support their family. Mrs. C. also weaves silk at home and her husband is a construction worker. Since her silk-weaving business is going well, Mrs. C. wants to expand and will use her loan to buy more silk.

loans.use: To buy silk for weaving

loans.name: Amina

texts.ru: Набиева Амина проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст, 49 лет. Замужем, имеет  8 детей. Образование среднее. Более 10 лет занимается шитьем национальных платьев. Она в основном берет заказы на даму.  Целью кредита является покупка ткани и бисера.
texts.en:
Amina N. lives in the Hamadoni district. She is 49 years old, married and has 8 children. She has a secondary education. Amina has been involved in sewing national dresses for over 10 years. She primarily takes in the orders at home. The goal of this loan is the purchase of fabric and beads.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of farbic and beads

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
Wilma P. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 45 years old. Wilma is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Wilma owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty food products in the local community. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Wilma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Wilma from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand his business.

loans.name: Merrylou

texts.en:
Merrylou C. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 25 years old. Merrylou is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Merrylou owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling specialty food products in the local community. Merrylou has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Merrylou joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merrylou is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Merrylou from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Daisy

texts.en:
Daisy B. is from the village of Bantuanon, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 48 years old. Daisy is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Daisy owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, operating a mini-restaurant. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from serving a variety of different meals to customers in the local community. Daisy has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 7,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Daisy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daisy is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase food and drinks for the restaurant. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Daisy from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase food & drinks for the restaurant.

loans.name: Imtiaz's Group

texts.en:
Imtiaz lives in a mid-sized city called Vehari in Pakistan. She owns a two room house where she has lived with her family for over 15 years. A very talented lady, Imtiaz is involved in an artificial flower making and selling business. She makes artificial flowers and sells them in the market to different decorative shops to help her family financially. She learned this skill from her mother who was involved in the same work.

Her husband's name is A. D., who operates a PCO (public call office, where people make a call and pay the call charges) in the market where he offers his clients national and international calls at cheap rates. He also sells calling cards to his customers. They both share their earnings to meet the financial expenses of the family. 

Imtiaz has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah, for her husband’s business. With the loan amount, her husband will buy telephone sets to offers his services to more people at a time and calling cards to sell to the customers. Imtiaz is hopeful that with the help of an investment her husband’s business will grow and his income will be increased.

This is a group loan. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

loans.use: To buy telephone sets & calling cards for public calling office.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia C. is from the village of Balila, Lantapan, Bukidnon. She is 56 years old. Eugenia is separated from her spouse and has 7 school-aged children. To make a living, Eugenia owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from buying and selling clothing and shoe products in the local community. Eugenia has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Eugenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eugenia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Eugenia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.name: Dilaram's Group

texts.en:
Dilaram J. is the leader of the group. She is 38 and married. She has a daughter and two sons. All the children are at school.  Dilaram works as a cashier and her husband is a truck driver. Dilaram applied for the loan because they need money to repair the truck. With money received from the loan she will purchase truck tires and a battery. In the future Dilaram wants to build a shop near the house and start selling convenience goods.

Nazgul K. is the treasurer of the group.  She is 35 and married. She has a daughter and two sons. All the children study at school. A year ago, with the initial investment of 3000 soms, Nazgul started to sell shoes at the market. In this way she makes 3000 soms per month. Her husband works as a taxi driver and when he is free he helps Nazgul with her activity. Nazgul hopes to obtain the loan because she needs money to purchase more shoes in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the near future she plans to purchase a container and then start repairing the house.

Zumrad K., 39, is married.  He has a daughter and a son. The son is at school and the daughter is not yet at school.  Zumrad works as a driver and his wife is a teacher at school. With money received from the loan he wants to purchase cement, windows, and paint in order to repair the house.  In the future he wants to open an auto repair center.

Almazbek A., 22, is married. In order to make money, he works in construction. He is also engaged in livestock breeding. He started to breed livestock two years ago with the initial investment of 5000 soms, and now is selling some animals after fattening, making 5000 soms per month.  With money received from the loan he wants to purchase two farm animals for breeding. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.name: Daisy Caballa Group

texts.en:
Daisy C. is from the village of Mialen, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Daisy is the group leader of a 4-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Daisy C. Group.

Daisy is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Daisy owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Daisy has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 10,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Daisy joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Daisy has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish to sell. Daisy is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Daisy from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna R. is 53 years old. She is a single parent and a good mother to her three minor children. They currently live in Hamtic, Antique. She has been engaged in a hog-fattening business for more than eight years and also gets involved in a variety store as another source of household income.

She plans to utilize this loan of 25,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) to expand her hog-fattening business and variety store and to continue to be involved in other businesses for supplemental profits. This loan will be used to support the maintenance of her hog-raising and pay for inventory for her store. She believes that her business will help her family to rise up and fight against poverty.

During her eight years as a member of ASHI, Myrna has shown very good performance with her group mates and center. Having this loan will enable her to finally achieve her dreams in life: to have a successful business, to fund the educational needs of her children until they finish college and to have a better life and a happy family as well. She is very thankful to ASHI and Kiva for the continuous support of her dreams.

loans.use: To support the maintenance of her hog-raising business and pay for inventory for her store

loans.name: Deo

texts.en:
In his late 40’s, Deo F. has been farming for over thirty years and is still at his best in showing fellow farmers in the area that he can make it. Motivated personally and by his parents for quite some time, hard-working Deo has grown a banana plantation, an onion, tomato and maize garden, and raised livestock. His farm is in Kasoga, Kyenjojo where he gets 700,000 UGX a month from these enterprises.

However, Deo’s main problem is small harvests, and so with this loan he will be able to purchase soil amendments like manure. This will make it possible for him to raise more and earn more to assist his family of seven children and a wife at home. His goals are to expand his business and educate his children who are still going to school.

loans.use: To purchase manure and fertilizers

loans.name: Lucy Wanjiku

texts.en:
Lucy Wanjiku is 44 years old and married to Samson Kamande, who is a teacher. They have three children. Lucy is a poultry farmer and has been in the business for a period of about three years with a monthly profit of 10,000 Kenyan shillings. 

She wants to use the loan to buy broilers. She was introduced to KADET by staff and this is her first loan. She hopes to build a greenhouse.

She would like to see her family live successfully so her children will achieve their dreams in life through education.

loans.use: To buy broilers

loans.name: Gorxmaz

texts.ru:
Gorxmaz X. 36 let. On jenat i imeyet 3 detey, starshaya dochka kotoroy 12 let ona uchitsya v shkole , dochka 10 let toje uchitsya v shkole i zanimayetsya tancami, sin 6 let v etom qodu poshel v shkolu. Gorxmaz yavlyayetya IDP personom , on pereselenec iz Kalbadjar, seychas On i yeqo semya projivayut v Absheron regione.

Gorxmaz 7 let tomu nazad nachal zanimatsya etim biznessom perevozki stroy materialov. Etomu biznessu yeqo nauchil dyada kotoriy toje rabotayet v takom biznese. Seychas Gorxmaz nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit zapchasti dlya svoyey mashini chtobi sdelat remont.
texts.en:
Gorxmaz X. is 36 years old. He is married and has 3 children. The oldest daughter, who is 12 years old, goes to school, 10-year-old daughter also goes to school and is learning dance, 6-year-old son started school this year. Gorxmaz is an IDP (internally displaced person). He is a refugee from Kalbadjar and now lives in the Absheron region together with his family. Gorxmaz started the business of transporting construction materials 7 years ago. He learned this business from his uncle, who also works in this business. Now Gorxmaz needs 2000 AZN to buy spare parts for his vehicle in order to make repairs.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of spare auto parts

loans.name: Big

texts.en:
Big S., 56, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. 

S. is a housewife while her husband is a militant, earning an income of $2.66 per day. One of the children is employed at a telecom company, earning an income of $8.33 per day to help cover the family expenses.  

S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase a truck for her husband to transport workers from the factory. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a truck to transport workers from the garment factory

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en: Erlinda G. is from the village of Malasin, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old. Erlinda is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda sells food and other products. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to have additional inventory and working capital. This will be the first loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To have additional inventory and working capital

location.town: Malasin, Dupax Del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Chum S., 29, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is a garment-factory worker, earning an income of $2 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of $4 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase a motorbike for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. is not available.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family to use

loans.name: Margaret Ene

texts.en:
Margaret has been rearing animals for sale in Naivasha town for the last six years. She is 22 years old. She is married to K. Ole Ita and they have two children.  

She was introduced to KADET by her friend and this will be her first loan. She plans to use the cash to buy 10 goats and five sheep, which she will rear and sell later at a profit.

Margaret also hopes to start processing animal skin and hide, which she will also be selling; this will diversify her stream of income.

loans.use: To buy 10 goats and five sheep, which she will rear and sell later

loans.name: Pov

texts.en:
Pov S., 31, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is a housewife, while her husband operates his truck to transport workers from the garment factory, earning an income of $8 per day.  

S. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice for the family to use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to grow rice

loans.name: Noah

texts.en:
Noah is a 49-year-old father of four. He is married to Eunice, who is currently in college furthering her studies. He runs a shop in the center near his home and he has been in the business for 13 years now. He also does farming on his farm and sells farm inputs to the residents around his home and at the center.

He learned about Kadet through an existing member and with this second loan, he plans to buy additional stock like flour, rice and other household materials.

He plans to open another shop at the center and diversify so that he is able to earn more income, which will enable him to educate all his children in good schools.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for his shop with things like flour, rice and others

loans.name: Yeth

texts.en:
Yeth C., 28, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Yeth sells palm fruit, earning an income of $4 per day. Her husband is employed at a rice factory in the province, earning an income of $3 per day.  

C. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase more palm fruit to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy more palm fruit to resell

loans.name: Hadicha

texts.ru: Очилдиева Хадича проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 26 лет. Разведена, детей не имеет. Живет вместе с родителями. Образование среднее. Занимается животноводством. Разводит скот в дальнейшем для перепродажи. В этой области более 4 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en:
Hadicha O. lives in the Shahrituz district. She is 26 years old, divorced and has no children. She lives together with her parents. Hadicha has a secondary education. She is inolved in animal husbandry and breeds livestock for future resale. She has been in this field for over 4 years. Hadicha is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle in order to increase its quantity.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo K., 38, is married and resides with his wife and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. K. and his wife sell cakes and snacks for kids, earning an income of $6.66 per day. 

K. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase more cakes and snacks to resell. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. K.'s wife and his son appear in the photograph because K. is not available.

loans.use: To buy more snacks and cakes to resell

loans.name: James Raita Ole

texts.en:
James Raita Ole K. is 34 years old and he supports a family of four. His spouse is Elizabeth K. and she has formal employment.

James is a businessman running a shop in Narok town. He sells blankets, bed sheets, wall curtains and materials for making clothes to the tailors who are his frequent customers. He has been in this business for the last nine years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who was already a registered member in KADET. This will be his fourth loan, which he is planning to use to buy more curtains and materials to increase his stock. He hopes to use the anticipated profit from this loan to expand his business and open up another shop.

James’s dream is to become a wholesaler and be a distributor in Narok town. He is a hardworking man with a great vision.

loans.use: To spend 25,000 Kenyan shillings to buy more stock

loans.name: Sempeta Ole

texts.en:
Sempeta Ole K. is 32 years old and married to Nasoi K.. He supports five people in his family. Sempeta is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land which he has been doing for last five years.

He learned about KADET through a friend who is already registered member in KADET. This will be his first loan which he is planning to spend to buy fertilizers to spray his ready growing wheat. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

Sempeta’s dream is to do larger scale farming, attain financial independence and improve the living standard of his family. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to spray the wheat he is growing.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria I. is a 47-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a fishing  business.  She lives in Sitio Mahayahay, Brgy. Daanlungsod, Bogo, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions through her own efforts and with the help of her loans from NWTF. By working hard in her fishing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 12000. Maria is now borrowing PHP 12000 so that she can purchase fishing materials. 

This will be her 6th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Maria aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the  Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of fishing materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim loves in Vehari, which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan, and is popular for its agricultural industry. She is married to M. R. who is a fruit seller by profession.  He sells fruits by putting them on his cart and visiting different streets of the city. He works very hard all the day to put three meals on the table for his family. 

Shamim helps her husband financially by making and selling "chingairs" (a kind of tray made of thick rope to keep breads in). She is very good in her art and her chingairs sells easily in the market at good rate. 

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner, Asasah for her husband’s business. With the loan amount her husband will buy seasonal fruits for his business.  She is hopeful that through this investment her husband will be able to make more income which will help her family to enjoy better facilities of life.

Note: In the picture, they lady who is raising her hand is Shamim.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Kheng

texts.en:
Kheng U., 61, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. U. is an actress in plays, earning an income of USD 2 per day. Her husband is an actor for the play and a police officer, earning an income of USD 3 per day.  

U. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  

This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. U. appears in the photograph with her family.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike for the family use

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a fifty-eight year old father of five children and married to Mrs Juliana, who is forty-nine years old. He runs a busy hotel at his home centre called Kapkangani, and in his free time he practices farming with the help of his wife. He has been in the hotel business for one year now and from it he makes a good profit.

He was introduced to Kadet through an existing client and with this first loan he plans to buy more stock for his hotel and acquire new furniture.

His future plan is to own a big hotel in the centre and to buy a plot and develop it.

loans.use: To buy stock for his hotel, i.e baking flour, cooking oil.

loans.name: Nanjiddash

texts.en:
Mr Nanjiddash is 31 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Currently they don’t own any land and are living on their relatives' land in a ger (traditional Mongolian nomadic tent). His son Bilguun, aged nine, attends a local school and daughter Enkhjin, aged one, stays at home. His wife Nyamerdene looks after the baby.

Mr Nanjiddash has been running a transportation business since 2005. In winter time he carries coal for coal dealers and in other seasons he transports goods between warehouses and markets. Sometimes he works as a delivery man. His normal working day starts at 8am and finishes at 9pm. He is a very hardworking and persistent man.

He is planning to buy a piece of land and to build a house on it. The loan he is requesting will be used to purchase a plot of land. He has already made a contract with a salesman to buy the land and now he has to pay the money for the land, according to the terms of the contract.

loans.use: To purchase a plot of land

loans.name: Seng

texts.en:
Seng S., 30, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. sews clothes for a play, earning an income of USD 2.66 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver and an actor for the play, earning an income of USD 2.33 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to purchase a tuk tuk to attach to her husband’s motorbike to improve his transportation business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S. appears in the photograph with her husband.

loans.use: To buy a tuk tuk to attach to the motorbike to improve the business.

loans.name: Sophie

texts.en:
Sophie N. lives in the Kanyanya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 1 child,  who is in school.  She also takes care of additional family member’s mother.

Sophie has a business of a pub.  She has been in this business for 6 years, and she works 7 days out of every week. Sophie sells her products in a shop, by means of retail.  Sophie has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more crates of beer.

She also generates additional income through selling breakables like cups, plates and glasses.The main business challenge for Sophie include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a beer depot and also build rental houses. She decided to join MCDT to boost her business by getting additional capital. Sophie lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication, and paying utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer.

loans.name: Moses Ochieng

texts.en:
Moses Ochieng O. is 43 years old and he supports five members of his family. His spouse is Redempta, who is a business woman and generates an income of about Ksh10,000. Moses is a tailor and he has been doing this business for the last ten years in a busy street in Narok Town.

He learned about KADET from market awareness done by staff within Narok Town. This will be his sixth loan with KADET and he has been paying the subsequent loans on time with no default. He is planning to spend the monies on buying more materials to add to his current stock. From the anticipated profit from the expanded business he anticipates being able to open up another shop in a different street within Narok town. 

His hope and dream is that he will own a house where he can operate his business and educate his children to a higher level. He is a hard working and business oriented man.

loans.use: To buy more materials to add to his current stock.

loans.name: Vat

texts.en: Vat T., 45, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. T. is a farmer, earning an income of USD 1.50 per day. Her husband is employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of USD 3.50 per day.  T. is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. T. appears in the photograph with her family.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for the family's use.

loans.name: Cristina Jose

texts.pt:
Cristina José Txavane comprou todo material acordado com Hluvuku e aplicou no proposito que se havia planificado.

Não foi possível pagar de acordo o calendário estabelecido devido ao atraso dos salários mas conseguiu pagar na totalidade e a sua obra esta decorrendo normalmente.

Houve mudanças na sua vida porque obteve mais um filho e com o novo empréstimo no valor de 20.000.00mt pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, areia, pedra, portas e outros) para dar continuidade com a construção da sua residência.

Sente se feliz com o empréstimo porque esta conseguindo dar melhores condições de habitabilidade a sua família. 
No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimo para concluir a sua casa.
texts.en:
[After getting a previous loan with Hluvuku, the Kiva field partner] Cristina José Txavane bought all of the materials agreed on with Hluvuku and began work on the project she had been planning. She was not able to repay the loan in the established time frame because of delays in the payment of her salary, but she did eventually repay the loan completely and her construction project is still underway.

There have been many changes in Cristina's life, including the birth of another child. She plans to use the new loan, for 20,000 Meticais, to buy construction materials (cement, sand, stone, doors and other items) in order to continue working on the construction of her home.

Cristina is happy with the loan because it is allowing her to provide better living conditions for her family. In the future she would like to apply for more loans to finish her house.

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, sand, stone, doors and other items)

loans.name: Jovita

texts.en:
Jovita A. is from the village of Siempre Viva Norte. She is 50 years old. Jovita is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Jovita owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Jovita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Jovita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 22,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. Jovita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 9th loan taken out by Jovita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Erdenetsetseg

texts.en:
Mrs Erdenetsetseg is 53 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in a suburb of Ulaanbaatar (the capital city of Mongolia). She also has two sons, who are grown up and live separately. Her husband works in a transportation company as a truck driver. The eldest daughter, Bayarmaa, 26, works with her mum. Her other daughter, Bayarjargal, 22, graduated from university this year and is looking for a job. Mrs Erdenetsetseg used to work in a clothing factory as a tailor and seamstress until 2004, when it was closed down.

That same year she rented a small workshop and started running a tailoring business making various dresses and clothes. Now she has gained valuable experience and has a loyal customer base. Mrs Erdenetsetseg is an energetic and enthusiastic person. Her family owns a plot of land and small house in a suburb of Ulaanbaatar. In the future they are planning to make some extensions and renovations to the house, therefore she needs to generate additional revenue by extending her business and increasing her working capital. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy two more professional sewing machines and more fabrics and materials for the business.

loans.use: To purchase sewing machines, fabrics and materials to expand a tailoring business

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita B. is a married woman who lives in Prk. Ipil-ipil, Brgy Vito, Sagay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating 3 business ventures: sari-sari (general) store, fishing, and pig fattening businesses. Her husband Francisco B., who is 45 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activities. Their only child is 19 years old. 

Carmelita  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1992 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 29 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Carmelita  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500, which was funded by Kiva lenders, helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 30th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 35,000, which she intends to use to purchase more stock to sell in her general store and also to buy a side-car for her motorcycle transport so that she can continue to save up for the future to sustain their daily needs and to educate her daughter. Carmelita B. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To prchase more stock to sell.

loans.name: Adolat

texts.ru: Мурадова Адолат проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 49 лет. Замужем, имеет 4 детей. Сыновья на заработках в России. Сама Адолат имеет среднее образование. Более 10 лет занимается животноводством. Она откармливает и продает скот. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота. На полученную прибыль хочет отремонтировать свой дом.
texts.en:
Adolat M. lives in the Shahrituz district. She is 49 years old, married and has 4 children. Her sons work in Russia. Adolat has a secondary education. She has been involved in animal husbandry for over 10 years. She fattens and sells livestock. Adolat is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle. She wants to use the resulting profit to remodel her house.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: James Mungai

texts.en:
James is 40 years old and is married to Ruth Njeri, a farmer who contributes to the family's income. They have three children. James runs and manages a butcher shop. He has been in the business for a period of about two years, with a profit of approximately 10,000 a month.

He is taking his first loan with Kadet, which he intends to use to add more stock of meat in order to meet the needs of his customers. He hopes to expand his business with the extra profit he makes.

loans.use: To buy more meat for sale to meet the customers' needs.

loans.name: Susana

texts.en:
Susana N. is 33 years old. She is married to Samuel Kuria who contributes to the family’s income, and they have two children. Susana is a dairy farmer and also keeps poultry. She has been in the industry for a period of about 10 years with a monthly profit of Kshs 12,100 per month.

She was introduced to KADET by her friends and she has applied for her first loan with us. She wants to use her loan to buy another cow and poultry feed. She hopes to buy a pick-up truck to assist her in transportation of farm products. 

Her dream is to buy a piece of land to develop a house for her family.

loans.use: To buy an extra dairy cow and poultry feed

loans.name: Mukhtaran's Group

texts.en:
Mukhtaran is a resident of Vehari which is a small city located in Punjab, Pakistan and famous for its agriculture industry. A very talented lady, Mukhtaran owns & operates an embroidery business.
