loans.name: Mrs. Nak Pon Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Twelve people make up a village bank loan located in Sdau Aem village in Takeo province. They have selected Mrs. Nak P., 50, as the village bank president. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Nak P. and her husband, Mr. Chan Nak Tom, are farmers who own a small piece of land to grow rice on. They sell their yield to support their family and they are also basket makers. Her problem is that it's time to grow rice, but her field is infertile and she does not have enough money to fertilize it. So, to improve production, Mrs. Nak P. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer. With any remainder of the loan she will hire a plow to plow her field and farming laborers. She is a mother of four children, one of whom is a jeweler, while two others are seamstresses in a garment factory, and the fourth is studying in school.

 Mrs. Seun Port is a group guarantor so she is also in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: 060104-Dai Giang-Hoang Chau Group

texts.en:
Triem N. T. (17) is a 53-year-old woman living in the town of Hoang Hoa.  Triem is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 060104-Dai Giang-Hoang Chau (060104-Dai Giang-Hoang Chau).

Triem is married and has 3 adult children.  To make a living, Triem operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  WhiL. not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for saL..  Triem has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 1,500,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2005, Triem joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Triem has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock.  She is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND which will be used to invest in expanding the business.  This will be the 6th loan taken out by the borrower from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Triem plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Thanh L. T. (112) is a 26-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 6000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  Loan C. T. (148) is a 48-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


3.  Tuyen L. T. (67) is a 28-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


4.  Huong N. T. (111) is a 30-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


5.  Chung N. T. (149) is a 35-year-old femaL. who is requesting a 5000000 VND loan to support her fishing business.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Triem N. T. (17) là 53 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang Hoa.  Triem là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 060104-Dai Giang-Hoang Chau (060104-Dai Giang-Hoang Chau).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi heo để bán.  Triem thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 6 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Triem kiếm được khoảng 1,500,000 VND.  Vào 2005, Triem đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Triem đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua con giống.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 6th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Thanh L. T. (112) là 26 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Loan C. T. (148) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  Tuyen L. T. (67) là 28 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Huong N. T. (111) là 30 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


5.  Chung N. T. (149) là 35 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Hun

texts.en: Hun H., 34, is married and resides with her husband and one child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. H. and her husband sell groceries, earning an income of USD 8 per day.  H. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a plot of land in a business area in the village to start up a grocery business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a plot of land in the business area of the village

loans.name: Guljamal's Group

texts.en: Guljamal B. is the leader of the group. She is 52 and divorced. She has raised a son and now he is 32. Guljamal works as an assistant of the deputy. She also cultivates fruits, vegetables and breeds cattle. She applied for the loan because she needs money to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the future, she wants to increase the number of cattle she has and achieve good results at her job. Tursun S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 52 and married. She has raised five children. Most of them are married and live separately with their families. Five years ago, with the initial investment of 50,000 soms, Tursun opened s shop and began to sell convenience goods. In this way, she makes 10,000 soms per month. Her husband is a pensioner, so when he is free, he helps Tursun in the shop. With money received from the loan, Tursun wants to purchase a variety of goods in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she wants to open another store and start selling shoes. Aida T., 40, is married. She has a son and three daughters. The son is in the army, two daughters are at school, and the third daughter is preschool age (under 7). Four years ago, with the initial investment of 20,000 soms, Aida and her husband started to sell secondhand clothes. In this way, they make 10,000 soms per month. With money received from the loan, Aida wants to purchase more clothes in order to increase the turnover of her business. In the future, she wants to expand her business and provide her children with a good education. Jenishbek B., 66, is married. He has four daughters and a son. All the children are married and live separately with their families. Jenishbek and his wife are pensioners. But the level of the pension is low, and they can’t cover their family expenses. So Jenishbek provides electrical services and also breeds cattle. He applied for the loan because he needs money to purchase more cattle for breeding. Medet A., 55, is married. He has two daughters and two sons. The first daughter is married and lives separately with her family and the other children are students. In order to make money, Medet and his wife breed cattle. With money received from the loan, Medet wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple "P" bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle

loans.name: Em

texts.en: Em S., 39, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. is a housewife while her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of USD 3 per day.  S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a motorbike for their children to use to commute to school. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. S.'s husband appears in the photograph because S. was not available.

loans.use: buy a motorbike for the children to use to commute to school

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida Q. is from the village of Bitnong Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 38 years old. Aida is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Aida owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector selling vegetables. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Aida has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Aida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Aida is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Aida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Bitnong Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Gordon

texts.en:
Very hard-working and determined to own a big farm in his home area of Kibirizi, Rukungiri, M. Gordon, aged 36 years, is a peasant farmer who grows food crops, owns a banana plantation, and normally sells off his produce to grocery and restaurant business dealers. 

 At length, he has built a strong determination that has played into his hands, and with hard working skills, he has gotten for his 4-year-old enterprise a dependable niche. Monthly profits to the tune of 100,000 Ugandan shillings is what he has been getting from banana and milk sales. With this loan he hopes to purchase fertilizers to help improve his agriculture and other farm inputs for the next season. This will in turn improve his yields, hence sales revenue will rise and he will be able to live a more satisfying life and educate his children, which is his main goal.

loans.use: agricultural farm inputs like fertilizers

loans.name: Sen

texts.en:
Sen P., 58, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. P. is a housewife while her husband is employed raising chickens, earning an income of USD 2.30 per day. Two of her children are employed and they are able to earn an income of USD 3 each per day. 

 P. is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase products from a company to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy products from a company to resell

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David K. is 45 years old . He is married to Racheal Nyambura and they have three children. His spouse contributes towards the income of the family. He has been farming for about 10 years with a profit of about 13,500 KES a month.

He wants to buy a chaff-cutter (to cut forage for his cattle) and with his profit he intends to buy another dairy cow. David hopes to buy a piece of land and improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: buy a chaff-cutter

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn Y. is from the village of Upper Centro, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Jocelyn is married and has three children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a business venture making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Jocelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Jocelyn is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 15th loan taken out by Jocelyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en:
Sourn S., 23, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. S. produces traditional baskets, earning an income of USD 2.30 per day. Her husband is a teacher for a local school, earning an income of USD 2 per day.  

S. is requesting a loan of USD 250 to pay her children's school fees. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: pay the children's school fees

loans.name: Nelius Wanjiku

texts.en:
Nelius is 30 years old married to Jacob Ngugi who is a businessman. They have two children: five years old and six months old. She has a farm where she gets her income. She has been in the industry for a period of about two years with a profit of 6,000 KES.  

She is taking her first loan with KADET and she wants to use the loan to expand her business. She hopes to have a wholesale shop which will see her children get educated and achieve their dreams in life and become responsible adults.

loans.use: To expand the business

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en: Rosalyn V. is from the village of Poblacion, Kalilangan, Bukidnon. She is 32 years old. Rosalyn is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalyn buys and sells rice grains in the local community. Rosalyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Rosalyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional rice to sell. Rosalyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Rosalyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and working capital

loans.name: Tarayia

texts.en:
S. is married and has five children: Sladoli, Sopiato, Nanyu, Solyo and Kapaai.

S. has been in the livestock business for eight years. He is servicing his first loan of 50,000 Kenyan shillings from KADET and he has no other loan with any other MFI (microfinance institution). S. was introduced to KADET LTD  through existing customers.

S. shall use the loan to add more livestock so as to meet demand. S. sells livestock to other busy markets. With the extra profits, he shall buy a lorry (truck) for transporting livestock.

S. describes himself as hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase more livestock

loans.name: Prum's Group

texts.en: This group loan has six members who live in Sdau Aem village in Takeo province. Mrs. Prum K., 57, is the group leader selected by the other members who will use their portion of the loan to improve their family's living standards. She is a farmer who owns a 1-hectare plot of land to cultivate rice on to sell to support her family. She has some problems because her rice field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, Mrs. Prum K. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer. With any remainder of the loan she will buy some piglets to raise to start a new business. Her husband, Mr. Ny Korng, is a basket maker. Based on the income from those activities, they support five children, all five of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Thirty-one-year-old Florence Nakityo has been teaching for the past 15 years in Kayunga town. She is a qualified teacher who notwithstanding the low remuneration has set a precedent in most schools she teaches in with her exemplary vigor and enthusiasm whilst she goes about her trivial round. This has in many respects gotten her into the good books of many school head teachers, who all speak glowingly of her high-spirited attitude and line of conduct.   

By her own account, teaching is a profession she is proud of and that is principally the reason she strives to give a good account of herself in whatever school she teaches in. 

Florence is single and has no kids but she has responsibilities that look her in the face every day. She says she is from an extended family and the onus has invariably been on her to pay school fees for her young brothers and sisters. The money she makes as a teacher at times shortchanges her and as a result, she is unable to fully pay up on time. With this loan, however, she says she will be able to meet all the financial school dues for her siblings on time.

loans.use: The school fees of her young brothers and sisters

loans.name: Pan

texts.en:
Pan S., 55, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. 

S. sells groceries and snacks, earning an income of $2.30 per day. Two of her children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of $80 each per month to help cover the family expenses. 

S. is requesting a loan of $500 to repair her house.

loans.use: To repair the house

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 44-year-old married woman who has three school-age children. She lives in Lebanon. She has been running a successful bakery for over a decade in her town. Her freshly prepared goods are enjoyed by members of her village and neighboring towns. She prepares delicious Lebanese breads and special products. 

Her business income is very vital because she helps her husband with building a new house. She has taken a first loan and she is pleased with her decision to take a loan from Ameen and satisfied with the loan amount. Today, she is requesting to borrow $2,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to improve her shop and attract more clients.

In the future, she is planning to continue expansion of her business and she is positive about the coming year. Lebanon has many pastry shops and bakeries and it is easy to buy fresh goods in one’s village or neighborhood.

loans.use: To improve her shop

loans.name: Carmela

texts.en:
Carmela L. is a married woman who lives in Brgy. Linao, Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating two business ventures: a general store and a mobile phone service electronic re-loading businesses. 

Her husband Jose L., who is 40 years old, works as a security guard to earn his living. They have an 8-year old child. 

Carmela joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2008 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Carmela has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 8000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 7500, uplifting the family's standard of living.  

This time, for her 5th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 12000, which she intends to use to  purchase more stocks to sell, so that she can continue to save up for future education of her child. Carmela L. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase more stock to sell

loans.name: Rowena

texts.en:
Rowena D. is from the village of Brgy. Payawan, Lamut, Ifugao. She is 33 years old, is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Rowena owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes  from selling personal products such as glasses and watches in the local community. Rowena has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rowena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rowena is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rowena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en:
Francis is a 40-year-old single man. For his living, he is tea farmer and has fish ponds. He has been in the industry for a period of one year with a monthly profit of about 16,000 KES. 

He was introduced to KADET by a friend. He wants to use the loan to improve his fish pond and his tea farm. He intends to use the accumulated savings to buy his own land. This is his second loan after repaying the previous one successfully without a problem.

loans.name: Pablita

texts.en:
Pablita M. is a married woman who lives in Purok  5-a, Campaclan village, Sibulan, Negro Oriental. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: herbal medicine, Panibit (nipa making) and RTW businesses. Her husband Rogelio M., who is 47 years old, works as a Construction Worker to earn his living. They have eight children who are 8 to 23 years old. 

Pablita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 11 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Pablita has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 28000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 8000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 12th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 29500, which she intends to use as additional capital for herbal medicine business so that she could continue to save up for future improve their family living condition. Pablita M. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. texts.en:
Mr. Kam S. who was born in 1965 is the village bank president, having been selected by the 18 members, who are located in Preak Ta Kaov village, Kandal province.  Each member of this loan group will use their portion of the loan to support their different businesses. 

Mr. Kam S. is a hard worker who works in lotus farming and fishing to support the family. With the funding from the loan, he was able to purchase fishing nets and fishing supplies. This loan is useful to him because his catch can be sold at a good profit. His wife, Mrs. Hun Chi, who is 53 years old, stays at home and cooks for her family. This couple has three children and they all work at different jobs.

loans.name: Philomena Njeri

texts.en:
Philomena K. is 42 years old. She is married to Stephen K. who is a singer and thus contributes to the family income. They have three children. She keeps poultry as her primary business, but wants to invest into rabbit rearing. She has been doing poultry for a period of three years getting a monthly profit of about Kshs 3000.

She was introduced to KADET by a staff member and she joined. She has applied for her first loan which she wants to use to develop the rabbit farm. She hopes to enhance her rabbit farming to a level where she will become a local supplier. This will enable her children to get good education which will enable them realize their dreams in life.

loans.use: To invest in rabbit keeping.

loans.name: Latofat

texts.ru: Муратова Латофат проживает в районе Шахритус. Возраст, 33 года. Замужем, имеет одного ребенка. Муж находится в России. Сама Латофат имеет среднее образование. texts.en:

She has been involved in animal husbandry for over 5 years. She breeds livestock at home. She primarily fattens and sells livestock. Latofat is requesting this loan for the purchase of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

texts.en:
Keo N., 47, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. N. sells groceries for an income of USD 3.5 per day. Her husband is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2 per day. The family has to spend  70 USD on food,  5 USD on electricity supply, 20  USD on children education, and10  USD  on transportation every month.  

Sreymom is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike for the family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her second loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.name: Demberel

texts.en:
Demberel L. is 55 years old and lives with his wife and two adult aged sons in Uvurhangai province in central Mongolia. The family members live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian tent home. Both of his sons works as assistant builders. Demberel owns and operates a small store in his town selling a variety of grocery and stationary products. His wife works as a servant for the local company. His grocery shop is located nearby school where attracts many customers. His monthly sales revenue is 500,000 MNT. Demberel started his shop in 2008 after moving from an other province and has built a stable operation. He is a very modest and accurate man. 

He is requesting a 900,000 MNT loan to purchase more inventory in order to increase his working capital.

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Zaituni N. lives in the Kamwokya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has five children, four of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (late bothers children).

Zaituni has a business of fish selling. She has been in this business for seven years and she works six days out of every week. Zaituni sells her products at the market, by means of retail.    

Zaituni has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more baskets of smoked fish. She also generates additional income through cooked food vending.

The main business challenges for Zaituni include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own  permanent business premises and also to start supplying smoked fish to different market vendors.   

Zaituni lives in a home that she rents; she doesn't have access to electricity but has access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and rent.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of fish

She get 5,000,000 VND per quarterly from selling pigs. Her husband helps her a lot in raising when she is busy with her shop. During the time she has been a member of our credit program, she has been a good re-payer. Currently, she wants to have a loan of  7,630,000 VND to  buy more kinds of vegetables to meet the demand of her customers.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 35-year-old married man and has four school-age children. He lives in Lebanon. He is the main income provider for his family; that’s why he works hard to satisfy their needs. 

He has 10 years of experience working as a farmer. He has been running his own farm since 2004. He uses plastic tents to grow his products. These tents also allow him to better monitor product quality as well as grow his products for more months during the year. He works independently in his business. 

Today, he is requesting a loan of $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l.  to purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work. With the help of the loan, he will enlarge his cultivation because he is planning to deliver the harvest to a bigger agriculture market and earn more income.

loans.use: To purchase needed supplies for his agricultural work

loans.name: Janessa

texts.en: Janessa P.'s main source of income comes from selling vegetables in her community. She is 21 years old, married and has two school-aged children. They are from the village of Eastern Wao, Lanao del Sur. Janessa has been in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2010, Janessa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Janessa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from HSPFI which was used to purchase additional vegetables to sell. Janessa is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. This will be her third loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna T. is from the village of Tabuan, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 48 years old. Edna is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Edna owns & operates a business buying and selling vegetables like eggplant, squash and others in the local community. Edna has been engaged in her business for over 18 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Edna joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edna is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Edna from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en:
Tungalag T. is a 52-year-old widow. She lives with her two children in a "ger," the traditional Mongolian housing tent, in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. Her oldest son is a student while her youngest son attends a local secondary school. Her husband passed away. 

Tungalag operates a tailoring business in her town. She has been engaged in this business since 2003 with her friend and they have built a successful business operation. After many years of business, she and her friend have managed to expand their business by operating in a popular location at the nearby local trade center. Her earnings have enabled her to pay her children's tuition fees and provide for her family. 

In the future, she plans to have her own workplace. Tungalag is a very modest and hardworking woman. She is requesting a 800,000 Mongolian tugriks loan to purchase necessary materials for her sewing business.

loans.use: To purchase necessary materials

loans.name: Anh

texts.en:
Anh T. N., 52, is the mother of two high school students. She is a rice and vegetable farmer.  Anh also raises and sells pigs to support her family.

She has received loans since 2004 to expand her business.  Currently, Anh wants a loan of 8,502,000 VND to buy 200 hens and hen food.

loans.use: Buy 200 hens and hen food.

loans.name: Van's Group

texts.en:
Van S. C. is a 34 year old married man who lives in Preak Ta Kaov village, Kandal province.   He was elected village bank president by his 16 members group.

Members will use their portion of the loan to purchase supplies, equipment and other item to support their families. 

Van is a fisherman, but he does not earn enough money to support his family. He is asking for a loan to buy a fishing boat and supplies for fishing.  His wife, Noy Vanna stays at home to care for their child.

loans.use: Buy fishing boat and supplies for fishing.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa D. is from the village of Tabuan, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 42 years old, married and has one school-aged child.  To make a living, Elsa makes and sells food, mostly cooked food for daily meals.  Elsa has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elsa joined GDMPC to access financial services to improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Elsa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be her first from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions of her family. 

----------------------------------------------
About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Janette

texts.en: Janette M. is from the village of Larion Bajo, Tuguegarao City. She is 42 years old. Janette is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Janette operates a manufacturing business. The main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing and selling simple knives to local businesses and community members. Janette has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. Janette joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Janette has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. Janette is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. This will be the second loan taken out by Janette from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Nga

texts.en: Nga T. T. N. is 45 years old and has two high school ages children.  She is a successful business woman who sells fertilizer and pesticides. Every month, she makes 3,000,000 VND profit.  Joining our credit program in 2007, she has a good repayment history. Currently, she wants a loan of 6,322,000 VND to invest in her shop.

loans.use: Invest in her shop.

loans.name: Eleonor

texts.en: Eleonor B. is from the village of Brgy. Payawan, Lamut, Ifugao. She is 40 years old. Eleonor is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Eleonor runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Eleonor has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Eleonor joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eleonor is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Eleonor from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina T. is from the village of Tabuan, Tukuran Zamboanga Del sur. She is 42 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Gina providing waste management and tricycle transport services. Gina has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Gina joined GDMPC to access financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business. Gina is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to repair an existing engine. This loan will her first from GDMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her living conditions. 

-------------------------------------------
About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.use: Repair existing engine.

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah N. lives in the Kazo Bwaise neighborhood, in the city of Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, all of whom are in school. Deborah lives in a home that she rents; she doesn't have access to electricity but has piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and rent.

Deborah has a business selling bananas. She has been in this business for seven years and she works six days out of every week. Deborah sells her products at the market, either wholesale or retail. She has requested a loan of 600,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy bunches of bananas. The main business challenges for Deborah include defaulters and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations are to educate her children up to the university level and also build her own house.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Hai

texts.en: Hai T. L. is 41 years old with two children who are in college.  She has a wood workshop and makes tables, desks and more under the order of local customers.  She  has manage her workshop  for four years. Every month, she earns about 4,000,000 VND profit. Currently, Hai wants a loan of 6,322,000 VND to buy wood.

loans.use: Buy wood as material.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en: Margret is a 45 year old woman, married with seven children. Three of her children are below 18 years of age. She lives in her own house located in Fort Portal, Uganda. She is a farmer and has been farming for ten years. This has enabled her to buy more land. However, she is constrained by the current climate change with uncertain seasons and prolonged dry seasons leading to low yields. Her family dream is to increase income levels for her household and her business dream is to become the leading farmer in the area. For this ambition to become a reality, she needs a loan to help her buy manure to boost the fertility of the soil so as to have increased production.

loans.use: To buy manure for her farm

loans.name: Mrs. Nai Nann Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In the Sdau Aem village in Takeo province there is a ten person group loan.  Nai N., 49, is the village bank president, selected by the other members who will use their portion of the loan for various pirposes.

Nai is a basket maker who sells baskets to her customers.  Her husband is a rice farmer. They work hard but earn a low income.  So, to improve her family Nai wants a loan to buy a cow. She is a mother of two children, one of whom is a seamstress in garment factory, while the other is a student.

loans.use: Buy a cow.

loans.name: 050106- Bac Hai- Hoang Phong Group

texts.en: Hoa N. T. (46) is a 48-year-old woman living in the town of H. Hoa. To make a living, Hoa operates a family member's specialized retail store selling health and medicinal products in her community. Hoa is married and has three adult children. Hoa has been in this business for over 26 years and earns approximately 1,500,000 dong (VND) a month. In 2007, Hoa joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enabL. her to engage in business activities. Hoa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1,626,900 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women which was used to purchase products to sell. She is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be her third loan from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Hoa plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the business. Hoa is the leader of a 6 member group accessing a loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is" 050106-Bac Hai-H. Phong". About the Other Borrowers in the Group: 1. Hanh H. T. (31) is a 40-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 2. Tham L. T. (9) is a 38-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 3. Chinh L. T. (45) is a 43-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 4. Hai L. T. (16) is a 34-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 5. Chien T. T. (6) is a 52-year-old woman who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her fishing business. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. Hoa N. T. (46) là 48 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố H. Hoa. Hoa là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 050106-Bac Hai-H. Phong (050106-Bac Hai-H. Phong). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ bán các sản phẩm chăm sóc sức khỏe & dược phẩm trong cộng đồng địa phương. Hoa thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 26 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Hoa kiếm được khoảng 1,500,000 VND. Vào 2007, Hoa đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Hoa đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 1,626,900 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua các sản phẩm bổ sung để bán. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Hanh H. T. (31) là 40 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. Tham L. T. (9) là 38 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 3. Chinh L. T. (45) là 43 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 4. Hai L. T. (16) là 34 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 5. Chien T. T. (6) là 52 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực thực phẩm. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là vận hành công việc kinh doanh hải sản. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Farizat's Group

texts.en: Farizat B. is the leader of this group. She is 35 and married with a son and three daughters. The son and two daughters are at school and the third daughter is not in school yet. Farizat is a farmer and she also breeds cattle to make money. Her husband provides tractor services. Farizat applied for a loan because she wants to increase her number of cattle. She makes money to cover family expenses by fattening cattle to sell at a higher price. In the future, she wants to purchase a piece of land and build a big new house for her family. Nurzaada S. is the treasurer of the group. She is 26 and married. She has two sons; both of them are preschool age (under seven). In order to make money, Nurzaada takes orders and sews national clothes and dressmaking supplies. Her husband is engaged in cattle breeding. With money from this loan, Nurzaada wants to purchase more cattle for breeding. In the near future, she plans to repair her house. Muranbek M., 40, is married. He has three sons and a daughter. The sons are at school and the daughter is not in school yet. Muranbek works in construction and his wife is a school teacher. They also breed cattle to sell after fattening. In this way, they make additional money to cover their family's expenses. With money from this loan, Muranbek wants to purchase cattle for breeding. Tunubek T. is 27 years old. He is a farmer. He applied for a loan because he needs money to purchase fuel and hire labor for the sowing process. In the future, he wants to get married and purchase a vehicle. Jyldyz K., 37, is married. She has a son and two daughters. The first daughter and the son are at school, and the second daughter is preschool age. In order to make money, Jyldyz sells flour on the market and her husband is a farmer. With money from this loan, they want to purchase fuel and hire labor. ====================================== Where Did This Loan Come From? This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). Mol Bulak is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135. If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase cattle
